I've tried learning guitar a few times in the past but it was boring and painful making it hard to stick with it.  This game isn't perfect but it gets so much right, you just want to keep coming back for more.  I hope this game has a very long life.One of the achievements was bass only so I decided to get the Electro-Harmonix PitchFork pedal so I could switch between playing all 3 paths (lead, rhythm, bass) at the press of a button.  That was a great addition to my setup and opened up all the bass items which are a lot of fun too.  I'm playing with a basic starter guitar: Epiphone Special II.Pros: The most motivating features for me were the achievements and the methods for grading your progress.  Each song has 5 ways of scoring your progress (Learn A Song percentage, 4 levels of Score Attack) that makes me want to ace them all.  Learn A Song supports a breadth-first progression through a song (gradually adding notes as you get better in each phrase) and Score Attack is an arcade-style depth first progression through a difficulty level (Easy, Medium, Hard, Master).  Master mode hides the notes and was scary at first but its a great motivator for weaning you off the sight-reading and encourages you to listen for cues instead.  Learn A Song also has Riff Repeater which allows you to mark a section and then slow it down and vary the difficulty level -- this is indispensible for getting those hard riffs down.  I also enjoyed working through the Lessons and Guitarcade.  Guitarcade is a collection of about a dozen games and they are an excellent way to get some technique practice in without feeling like you're doing something as boring as scales.  I'd really like to see more of these mini-games as they are much more fun than practice exercises.Cons: Ubisoft sites really suck at consistency.  Achievements and unlocks are shown on the Ubisoft site, the Rocksmith site, and Steam.  Steam is rock solid but the others are woefully inconsistent and aggravating to use.  500 missions?  Really?  What an annoying achievement!  Guitarcade's Hurtling Hurdles seems much too sensitive and poorly balanced compared to the other games.  Session mode -- the mission system kept pushing this but I found it a dreadful bore since I'm not good enough to improvise anything interesting at this point.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
												I can't praise this game enough. I love all forms of rock and soft metal music. From a very early age I always wanted to play guitar but will openly admit that my skills don't match my enthusiasm. Many years ago I tried electric guitar and wasn't very good. I eventually gave up through lack of improvement and and injury where I lost my left middle finger tip. It wasn't until just over a year ago when I was fancying the idea of trying guitar again. Because of my finger I thought about trying bass and out of the blue my girlfriend bought me a bass starter set for my Christmas present. I was immediately hooked but again my enthusiasm exceeded my skills, then I came across Rocksmith 2014. For me it has been a revelation and although I accept the purist musicians might not think it's great for people like myself that have a love for music but lack the skill it is a must to have. I don't have a very good memory and can't really play son's without out the help of Rocksmith 2014 but the big incentive is that I can now play music to which I consider a pretty good standard. I am now the guy that has all the gear and no idea lol. I bought myself a Schecter stiletto custom 4 bass with an Orange bass amp and various pedals and use Rocksmith to compliment them. While i'm realistic and know that i'm no Duff McKegan I couldn't have achieved what I have without rocksmith and in the end of the day I have fun and enjoy it which is what it's all about. For other people like myself I couldn't recommend Rocksmith 2014 enough. I would like to add that what you get for the price is an understatement. I would dread to think how much money I would have spent on lessons to get to the stage i'm at. While I accept with tuition I might be at a better standard for the cost difference involved it doesn't compare. Also initially I played this on my PS3 but moved to using my PC as I love being able to have such a massive library of custom songs available to me through customforge.comI can honestly say that I only have found two drawbacks but this is not due to the game itself as the things I am doing are outwith what the game was originally designed for. I'm a bit of a gadget geek and I use Rocksmith via my amp and tv for sound by using a switch blade+ spliter which can sometimes cause issues with the real tone cable and also the game very rarely crashes after prolonged use using custom songs. But as I say these aren't official features of the game so it's unfair to mark it down on these cases.

												I've always wanted to play guitar but every time I've tried I got to a point where I'd get bored, reading tabs was confusing for a beginner and I was really having trouble with chords. content:
ber 18, 2016
												Rocksmith is an amazing way to improve your guitar & bass playing abilities, jam, learn new songs, and even discover new artists. I've been playing bass guitar since I was 16. I haven't been in a band for 5 years and it's hard to stay sharp and find time to practise. Also, bass is a pretty boring instrument to play by yourself. I continue to write and produce music independently and Rocksmith is a great way to get through the grind of practise. The game works great with my basses and electric guitar. It also works really well with my classical acoustic (which has a built in pickup). The acoustic has been a very fun way to play too since I have the heavy guitar tone coming out my headphones, but I can hear the body of the acoustic as well which confirms that I'm actually playing something nice.I had no idea I like Metalcore, but after playing an Avenge Sevenfold track on bass I've spent my whole weekend mastering all of their songs. Thanks Ubisoft!I've played with the settings and have only 2ms latency with the real tone cable which I'm very comfortable playing with. My DAW tpyically runs at 5ms, so as an audio processing app it's pretty legit. There are also amp modelling modes and an effects board. The tones in this mode are really great, however it is difficult to use the menus to really dive deep into all the functions. My guess is that the menus were designed for console and not PC.One thing that I would love would be the ability to set my own tuning in the game and have the tracks update as per my bass config. I play a 5-string bass so for a SOAD song I can just as easily play on the low-B rather than tuning my whole setup to drop C. Also some songs are very reliant on open notes which I personally don't like, I'd like to be able to say rather than going open D, playing the 5th fret on the A string. This is all nit picky stuff though, the game is amazing.The songs bundled with the game cover so many genres that there really is something for everyone. The DLC has been great since day one. I've bought DLC for Avenge Sevenfold, Motley Crue, Iron Maiden, Deftones, Killers, Strokes, Smashing Pumpkins, Rush, and Pantera. I plan on buying a whole lot more but I need to master a few tracks in my library first!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
8
												This is an first impression review, after playing like about an hour. Most important thing: Buy the Ubisoft Real Tone cable and dont try another one. I did, and its only a mess. Ubisoft cable works perfectly, plug & play. The other calbe didnt work.Second: People are complaining about delay. THIS IS JUST NOT TRUE. Maybe it depends on your overall system setup. Maybe you play too slow. Maybe you dont grasp the display and when to play. I didnt exerience any delays yet. Timing is good.In the beginning the display is not easy to understand. I had the impression that they dont explain much and just throw you into the cold water. So you try to hit the right tones and understand the display while playing. Its ok, because you need to put some effort in terms of thinking and attention into it. So its a bit challenging in terms of usability in the first place. But its not bad and I had the impression its all thought through quite carefuly.The software is quite smart. I tried the lead guitar mode. You pick a song you like. And it makes you play single tones of that song, but with a lot of time distance between the tones, so you have enough time to undestand what to do and when and find the right tone to play. When you get better or are good already the software increases the density of the tones successively and according to your progress. Quite smart.Fun thing is: When you hit the right tones or several in a row, the audience is screaming in the background. Quite nice. After you completed the song, the software might even praise you. :DThe strings you have to play have different colors in the display, which is nice since it connects your visual imagination with your hearing. I like that very much. The whole experience also improves connecting listening, playing and singing at the same time. It really makes you want to sing and play all at once. Its all quite encouraging and makes your neurons connect and firing. A small minus is, that for advanced players it might be interesting to see where to put several of your fingers at once, so you could increase the speed of playing and switching from one tone to another. The display only shows you single tones to play and if you dont know in advance where to put your fingures and are not experienced how this usually works you dont know how to play it fast enough. Hence, I think the software cannot stand for its own. Its an addon to other. more traditional sources of learning. Get to know tabs or get a teacher or online learning.I think the software is good to either learn some basics or have it as a kind of addon and it is a different playing experience with the features of connecting different of your senses. It makes you practice and play a bit, its fun to do and gives you some motivation and smiles. Hence, it's a smart software with some nice features and ideas to it and I like it. For beginners it might be a good basic start and for advanced players a nice addon or different experience with some benefits to it. If I had to rate it would get a grade "B"or maybe like a 7.5 out of 10.

content:
er 12, 2015
												Decent learning tool. Defintly for novice guitarists like myself to lean the ropes.  However it is not perfect.The note detection is hit and miss. How the tracks are set up, slowly adds notes once you hit a track perfectly or removes them when you miss a fraction, is a decent idea. Once you put it into practice though it is psychologically frustrating. Here is why. Once you learn a riff on a lower dificulty you have to relearn that riff again when the difficulty ramps up. Subconsciously you are relearning a single song multiple times over and over again. Then muscle memory will not have a clear memory to focus on. Leading to frustration for guitarists. No matter who I talk to about Rocksmith is irritated with the software.You can however max out the song and play at slower speeds then manually make them faster over time. This slightly less irritating because hitting/missing unkown chords or riffs will continue regardless. What would make it better is for the a training mode to stop a track until you hit the note or the chord perfectly then move to the next one to get a taste of the dish. Then move on to nonstop tracks. Occasionaly, on my rig anyway, the chord is very picky about how it is placed in the guitars output. Buzzing sounds cut off all outputs as well as the output cutting off alltogether. Rocksmith provides a lot of information and is a decent escape for bordem. But you could search for the same information online for free.

content:
6, 2015
												Pretty dissapointed with the song selection, but it's still a cool game.Now what it REALLY needs is a mode that completely stops the song on every note and waits for you to play it before moving to the next, rather than flying them all past your screen. Because note by note is how we read and play tabs, right? You look down at the note, play it on the guitar, and move onto the next; it's not as if your eyes skim past the tab while your fingers helplessly play catch-up, but that's how this game does it.Granted, you can emulate something close to that with their Riff Repeater mode set to 1% speed, but that also isn't perfect.The note-by-note function is already present in the very start of the game, but you never see it again after that. I just wish the developers provided an option to play songs using that.

content:
ber 4, 2014
												Before I had ever heard of this game, I had bought a guitar years ago. I always wanted to learn, but never came through to learning how to play a song. I had once in a while picked up the guitar and strummed a few cords, just for the heck of it. Until December 2013 I heard about this new program called Rocksmith 2014, and although I've heard about the Rocksmith 2011 and I heard reviews that the 2011 edition was not accurate guitar teacher, I passed for buying the game. Since I heard about this new 2014 edition, I seemed interested on what all the fuss was about. After reading reviews and watching videos, I finally decided to buy the game. When plugging in my guitar for the first time, I was confused with scheme of the game. When I reversed of to the Learn a Song section, and played a song, I was confused with the notes and did not seem to be getting anywhere to playing the actual song. However, after playing the song for about a half-hour, the notes started to adjust to my ability as I learned the song more and more. I even used the handy riff repeater that can strengthen my skills within the notes of the song by speeding up or slowing down, and/or adjusting the difficulty. The game includes mini games if you ever get bored of Learn a Song and want to practice chords, finger picking, or just strumming the guitar. Don't worry too much about the option as I focus much with Learn a Song and the mini games. And after 8 months and 20 hours of practicing, not including off time practicing, I have learn about 10 songs fully. And the worth the price rather than paying a guitar teacher, in addition to paying the game on your own time. -Also supports bass :P

content:
, 2016
												So to start this review off , I started playing guitar 6 months ago and I bought Rocksmith roughly 5 months ago I suppose. So this review is by an actual beginner guitar player.Rocksmith really is a great tool if you want to learn how to play e-guitar , more speficially said it helps you play your favorite songs. There are technique lessons in there that you can tune in to and it might help you get better at the overall guitar playing techniques. the different scales are also included, so if you want to deeply delve into stuff like that , it gives you the most basic informations, but I guess further research is requiered.But now the most important part about Rocksmith. Does it help, wil you get better at guitar and just as important , is it even fun?Yes, Yes and Yes.It helps- It's just TAB's made into a graphic game basically. You play it kinda like the Guitar Hero games , hit the notes/acc/bendings/etc when they hit your screen.One of the biggest benefits for a beginner is the visualization of the Rhythm. It's much easier to memorize the rhythm when you kinda see when , which and how often you have to hit each strings.Furthermore there are quests that help you to be diversive, which brings us to the next point....It helps you to get better at your guitar playing.Even in the standard game there's a good bunch of songs that range from country to metal , from very easy beginner friendly songs too songs that are for more experienced players.The quests kinda motivate you to try out songs that you normally would'nt have touched and this will not only broaden your horizon in terms of music , it will also help you too see and use techniques that you wouldn't have used otherwise.I can only give you the advice to try a majority of the songs. Even if you dont like them , they might be fun to play and since you bought the game anyways you own them.And ofc , yes it is fun. It's fun because it is an easy and kinda "fast" way to learn the guitar. Is it the fastes like Ubisoft describes it? I doubt it , since every human being learns different. But alongside the song's you also have funny little minigames that are educational and let your train your chords , bendings , scales etc.It's also just a fantastic feeling to rock out your favorite songs and learning them, until you can play them without Rocksmith with your home equipment.What brings me to my last point , the sound of the ingame Amps.The guys that decipher the songs note for note and try to get the tone for the song as real as possible , they do a great job. On all the songs I own , the sound is very close to the original.But on the otherhand , the ingame amp sound without the original tones from the songs is not the best in my opinion , I would not want to use this for any kind of playing besides Rocksmith.But there's also a major problem with the game that I don't think will be ever fixed.Some of the bendings in some particular songs track very horrible and playing with a very low tuning like Drop C can be frustrating , some notes , strings and chords get veeeerrrry poorly detected.You can still learn the rhythm and tabs however.A quick summarize.Positive+ It helps you start your guitar hobby and helps you to continuesly get better at it+ You can very easily learn your favorite songs and discover new bands/tracks that you never heard off+ You can learn probably the majority of the most important techniques and scales+ The tone of the songs is very close to the original tone , on the other hand....Negative - .... the standard ingame amp seems to lack a good tone. might be only my configs though.- Bendings get sometimes very badly recognized- If you want to play in low tunings like Drop C , be prepared to be frustrated. I would recommend getting thick strings , they tend to help the real-tone cable to recognized your chords better when tuned down.- CARE THERE ARE SONGS OUT THERE THAT REQUIRE A CAPO. (ex. "WONDERWALL")I hope my review might help you guys

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
18, 2016
												About me:I starting playing guitar in January of this year and bought the game two months later. I am playing on a Yamaha FSX700SC acoustic. Although music has been a part of my life for many years, this is the first time I have tried to learn a traditional instrtrument. Rocksmith 2014 is a great tool for learning songs and techniques without requiring the use of teachers or traditional self help books and videos. I do not recommend using this game as the only resource for learning the guitar but it is a great adjunct for players learning in a more traditional way. The learning curve has felt daunting and frustrating at times but patience and persistance has helped me learn some really cool stuff from this game. With that said, there are some things that this game cannot teach you:Strum patterens are covered in some detail in the Lesson mode but the game never indicates if you need to strum up or down. This makes playing 'rhythm' songs that are very chord heavy almost impossible unless you are already familiar and comfortable with this concept. Same with alternate picking; there is a lesson on it but beginners will inevitably have bad habits because the game has no way of knowing or correcting your technique. Learning outside of the game seems crucial for really getting better down the road.Now here's what this game can teach you:Self help books and videos are great when it comes to timing, strum patterns, and reading sheet music but one thing I love about this game is that you are playing real songs which means you are constantly playing up and down the neck. Books and sheet music for a beginner feel restricted because it is a very slow process. Learning scales and keys means that you are only working with a limited amount of frets at one time. This game has helped me learn which string/fret represent each key in a way that is fun and fast.Chords are obviously essential and this game is worth it for the chord book alone. Learning all the different shapes and barre chords can seem daunting but this method of learning is a lot more intuitive and fun. I really like how it tells you the chord names as you are playing/learning a song.My experience with playing the game on acoustic has been alright. Electric might be better for this game because a lot of the songs were originally played that way. Also, there can be some sound issues with acoustic because of how loud they are but the 'Mixer' option let's you tweak the sound to your liking. If you are thinking of picking up a guitar for the first time this game is an essantial learning tool. Learning the guitar without real lessons or a teacher can be almost impossible in the long run but this game is the beginning of something exciting. I credit this game for the majority of my current skills with guitar, and who knows where I would be in terms of skill without it. Sure, I may have bad habits in some areas but the gratifying feeling of playing real songs and learning real concepts is unparalleled to other methods of learning.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												I saw a guitar teacher in a video on the Internet say that it takes about 3,000 hours of practice for someone to really become decently competent at the guitar. His point was simply that there was no substitute for putting in the time, and no real shortcuts  - though of course good instruction (such as his own) would help.RS2014 went away from its more "gamey" style predecessor to become more of a full-fledged training tool for the guitar. This was a good move. It's easily three times better than the original Rocksmith at meeting this goal. Everything is much, MUCH more instructive and convenient. It gives you lots of tools to learn popular (and not-so-popular) songs... really learn them, to the point where you can completely play them from memory. From the basic "Learn a song" tool to the flexible "Riff Repeater," which allows you to practice a section of a song over and over again, to the ability to test yourself at various skill levels in Score Attack - which is a lot like classic Guitar Hero / Rock Band type play. But it also includes dozens of lessons - many with practice tracks. And a number of "Guitarcade" technique games to take some of the boredom out of common drills. You can simulate a large number of amps, cabinets, and effects to simulate all kinds of tones and use the game like a sound system and amp - and to learn how your favorite band got a particular tone for a particular song. `There's a "Session Mode" where you can practice jamming and improvising with a computer-controlled band. The game supports lead guitar, rhythm guitar, *AND* bass techniques - including a "bass emulation" mode to learn to play bass on a regular six-string guitar. And there's multi-player (really 2-player) capability, so a friend can plug in (with another cable, which currently runs $30) and the two of you can learn songs together, jam together in Session mode, play a duet with different song parts for a high score, and go head-to-head in a competition at the same difficulty level and part to see who is the better player.The game isn't perfect in detecting the notes, and will allow some sloppiness in your playing that does not sound good to the human ear. Unplugging or adjusting the mix and really listening to yourself is a must, or you could develop some bad habits because the game will let you get away with it.Ultimately, the success of the game is dependent on how successful it is at teaching you to play guitar. It's supposed to be "the fastest way to learn guitar." I don't know if that's exactly the case. But I will say this - it's helped me make more progress in the last six months than I had in twenty years on my own, so that's a good sign. I've been playing about 45 minutes per day, on the average, and it's really made a difference.But the important thing to remember is that it doesn't work miracles. If you think you can master the guitar in the time it takes for you to master Super Mario Brothers, you are going to be disappointed. You won't go from being a beginner to playing like Eddie Van Halen in 60 hours. That 3000 hour thing is not super flexible. The game does help in two ways:1) It can provide lots of feedback and support to help make your practice time more efficient. This may yield somewhat greater improvement per hour of practice than doing so unaided.2) It can make your practice time more fun, which may encourage you to practice more, and stick with it. And that's really all it can do, though that's awesome. In the end - if you want to learn to play guitar, you are going to HAVE to put in the hours. There's no way around that. If RS2014 makes those hours more productive and more fun (and I believe it does), that's a win!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
24, 2014
												See my full review with screenshots and more at http://misstoxia.com/review-rocksmith-2014/Rocksmith 2014 is both a game and learning tool for use with a real electric guitar or bass. You plug in your guitar to a USB port with a special cable and can play through step by step guitar lessons, learn specific songs and riffs and play a variety of arcade style games with your guitar as the controller.Everything the game does is done in a very incremental, adaptive and intuitive way, from the games to the lessons, everything is designed to help you retain information about notes, chords and scales, etc, as well as building up your muscle memory to improve your skill at playing guitar. It’s obvious a lot of work and research has gone into making Rocksmith 2014 a powerful education tool that can teach anyone to play guitar while still being fun.The lessons try to teach you how to play in the way a real guitar tutor would; by explaining techniques, showing you how they are played and then giving you a go while gradually making things more advanced each time. The practice riffs also slow down and let you do things at your own pace if it thinks you are having trouble.There are also a decent amount of ‘Learn a Song’ songs that come with the game that start you off by getting you to play the very base notes that hold the song together, the game reacts to how well you are doing and gradually adds in more notes if you are getting everything right, eventually the notes will become chords and with enough practice you will easily learn how to play a song from start to finish.The arcade games are designed to make you remember specific aspects of guitar playing as well as increasing your reaction time, muscle memory and being able to play without looking at the guitar neck. One game has you shooting ducks by playing the right note as they appear in front of different frets, another has you strumming entire chords in a zombie rail shooter. I found all the games to be both fun and very helpful.Some other nice features Rocksmith 2014 has is a full tone designer where you can create your own digital sound using a variety of pedals, amps, loops and more. The real life equivalent of this kind of equipment is really expensive so I found it really fun to be able to play around with this kind of stuff. There’s also multiplayer modes, online leaderboards and session mode where you have an automatic band accompanying your guitar as you play.I don’t have many bad things to say about Rocksmith 2014 other than the song selection not being entirely to my taste, but a few DLCs fixed that for me. I also had an incredibly hard time getting a Rocksmith RealTone cable in Australia, all of the retail stores were sold out for over a month and I had to order one online. Some may also argue that the game is too repetitive, but with learning any instrument, repetition is the key to success and I think this game really makes the repetition as fun as it can possibly be.If you have a guitar sitting in the corner of your room which you don’t really play because you’ve given up on learning it on your own, then I highly suggest you try Rocksmith 2014, you will almost definitely improve at playing guitar, learn some new songs and have lots of fun. If you want to learn guitar on your own, this is the way to do it.

You can simulate a large number of amps, cabinets, and effects to simulate all kinds of tones and use the game like a sound system and amp - and to learn how your favorite band got a particular tone for a particular song. `There's a "Session Mode" where you can practice jamming and improvising with a computer-controlled band. The game supports lead guitar, rhythm guitar, *AND* bass techniques - including a "bass emulation" mode to learn to play bass on a regular six-string guitar. And there's multi-player (really 2-player) capability, so a friend can plug in (with another cable, which currently runs $30) and the two of you can learn songs together, jam together in Session mode, play a duet with different song parts for a high score, and go head-to-head in a competition at the same difficulty level and part to see who is the better player.The game isn't perfect in detecting the notes, and will allow some sloppiness in your playing that does not sound good to the human ear. Unplugging or adjusting the mix and really listening to yourself is a must, or you could develop some bad habits because the game will let you get away with it.Ultimately, the success of the game is dependent on how successful it is at teaching you to play guitar. It's supposed to be "the fastest way to learn guitar." I don't know if that's exactly the case. But I will say this - it's helped me make more progress in the last six months than I had in twenty years on my own, so that's a good sign. I've been playing about 45 minutes per day, on the average, and it's really made a difference.But the important thing to remember is that it doesn't work miracles. If you think you can master the guitar in the time it takes for you to master Super Mario Brothers, you are going to be disappointed. You won't go from being a beginner to playing like Eddie Van Halen in 60 hours. That 3000 hour thing is not super flexible. The game does help in two ways:1) It can provide lots of feedback and support to help make your practice time more efficient. This may yield somewhat greater improvement per hour of practice than doing so unaided.2) It can make your practice time more fun, which may encourage you to practice more, and stick with it. And that's really all it can do, though that's awesome. In the end - if you want to learn to play guitar, you are going to HAVE to put in the hours. There's no way around that. If RS2014 makes those hours more productive and more fun (and I believe it does), that's a win!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
24, 2014
												See my full review with screenshots and more at http://misstoxia.com/review-rocksmith-2014/Rocksmith 2014 is both a game and learning tool for use with a real electric guitar or bass. You plug in your guitar to a USB port with a special cable and can play through step by step guitar lessons, learn specific songs and riffs and play a variety of arcade style games with your guitar as the controller.Everything the game does is done in a very incremental, adaptive and intuitive way, from the games to the lessons, everything is designed to help you retain information about notes, chords and scales, etc, as well as building up your muscle memory to improve your skill at playing guitar. It’s obvious a lot of work and research has gone into making Rocksmith 2014 a powerful education tool that can teach anyone to play guitar while still being fun.The lessons try to teach you how to play in the way a real guitar tutor would; by explaining techniques, showing you how they are played and then giving you a go while gradually making things more advanced each time. The practice riffs also slow down and let you do things at your own pace if it thinks you are having trouble.There are also a decent amount of ‘Learn a Song’ songs that come with the game that start you off by getting you to play the very base notes that hold the song together, the game reacts to how well you are doing and gradually adds in more notes if you are getting everything right, eventually the notes will become chords and with enough practice you will easily learn how to play a song from start to finish.The arcade games are designed to make you remember specific aspects of guitar playing as well as increasing your reaction time, muscle memory and being able to play without looking at the guitar neck. One game has you shooting ducks by playing the right note as they appear in front of different frets, another has you strumming entire chords in a zombie rail shooter. I found all the games to be both fun and very helpful.Some other nice features Rocksmith 2014 has is a full tone designer where you can create your own digital sound using a variety of pedals, amps, loops and more. The real life equivalent of this kind of equipment is really expensive so I found it really fun to be able to play around with this kind of stuff. There’s also multiplayer modes, online leaderboards and session mode where you have an automatic band accompanying your guitar as you play.I don’t have many bad things to say about Rocksmith 2014 other than the song selection not being entirely to my taste, but a few DLCs fixed that for me. I also had an incredibly hard time getting a Rocksmith RealTone cable in Australia, all of the retail stores were sold out for over a month and I had to order one online. Some may also argue that the game is too repetitive, but with learning any instrument, repetition is the key to success and I think this game really makes the repetition as fun as it can possibly be.If you have a guitar sitting in the corner of your room which you don’t really play because you’ve given up on learning it on your own, then I highly suggest you try Rocksmith 2014, you will almost definitely improve at playing guitar, learn some new songs and have lots of fun. If you want to learn guitar on your own, this is the way to do it.

content:
18, 2016
												About me:I starting playing guitar in January of this year and bought the game two months later. I am playing on a Yamaha FSX700SC acoustic. Although music has been a part of my life for many years, this is the first time I have tried to learn a traditional instrtrument. Rocksmith 2014 is a great tool for learning songs and techniques without requiring the use of teachers or traditional self help books and videos. I do not recommend using this game as the only resource for learning the guitar but it is a great adjunct for players learning in a more traditional way. The learning curve has felt daunting and frustrating at times but patience and persistance has helped me learn some really cool stuff from this game. With that said, there are some things that this game cannot teach you:Strum patterens are covered in some detail in the Lesson mode but the game never indicates if you need to strum up or down. This makes playing 'rhythm' songs that are very chord heavy almost impossible unless you are already familiar and comfortable with this concept. Same with alternate picking; there is a lesson on it but beginners will inevitably have bad habits because the game has no way of knowing or correcting your technique. Learning outside of the game seems crucial for really getting better down the road.Now here's what this game can teach you:Self help books and videos are great when it comes to timing, strum patterns, and reading sheet music but one thing I love about this game is that you are playing real songs which means you are constantly playing up and down the neck. Books and sheet music for a beginner feel restricted because it is a very slow process. Learning scales and keys means that you are only working with a limited amount of frets at one time. This game has helped me learn which string/fret represent each key in a way that is fun and fast.Chords are obviously essential and this game is worth it for the chord book alone. Learning all the different shapes and barre chords can seem daunting but this method of learning is a lot more intuitive and fun. I really like how it tells you the chord names as you are playing/learning a song.My experience with playing the game on acoustic has been alright. Electric might be better for this game because a lot of the songs were originally played that way. Also, there can be some sound issues with acoustic because of how loud they are but the 'Mixer' option let's you tweak the sound to your liking. If you are thinking of picking up a guitar for the first time this game is an essantial learning tool. Learning the guitar without real lessons or a teacher can be almost impossible in the long run but this game is the beginning of something exciting. I credit this game for the majority of my current skills with guitar, and who knows where I would be in terms of skill without it. Sure, I may have bad habits in some areas but the gratifying feeling of playing real songs and learning real concepts is unparalleled to other methods of learning.

content:
y 1, 2015
												Rocksmith 2014 is a great starting point for anybody that has wanted to learn the guitar.  For a long time I've wanted to learn how to play but never had the means or resources to do it.  Like most people I got hooked into the whole Guitar Hero and Rock Band craze which was fun but at the end of the day it did nothing to help me learn the guitar.  If I could take all those hours of playing those games and invested it into Rocksmith who knows how much better I would be.  Games like Rock Band and Guitar Hero had one thing going for them in my opinion: They made me realize how much fun it was to be "playing" music that I liked.  Fast forward a few years and I learned about Rocksmith.  I researched the game a bit and saw some videos which demonstrated how the game worked.  In theory the game sounded amazing: a way to learn how to play songs that I like (and discover some new ones) with a real guitar.  I was skeptical at first because on one hand it would require you to own/buy/borrow a real guitar to do it.  After a few months I broke down and went to Guitar Center to buy a guitar to play.  I first purchased the game for the PS3 off of Amazon because it shipped with the Real Tone cable and it was on sale.  Firing up the game for the first time the game asks you a few basic questions about your skill level and your guitar.  The game boasts that you can enjoy it whether your a pro or never touched a guitar in your life.  There are a variety of lessons that range from the basics (how to hold the guitar, put the strap on, and intro to chords) to more advanced techniques like palm mutes (and other techniques that I'm nowhere close to trying).  There is a session mode where you can jam with a virtual band that will jam along with you while you mess around with all the tools they offer.  The other instruments will play differently depending on how fast or slow you play.  There is the Guitarcade mode where you can play mini games designed to help you work on different skills.Finally there is the Learn a Song mode which I probably where I spend most of my time.  There is quite a collection of music and it spans many genres.  Since purchasing this for the PC I've also picked up some extra songs whenever they go on sale (usually during the holiday sales).  Most of the songs have three different paths you could play on any particular song: Lead, Rhythm, or Bass guitar.  Once I started playing the notes were few and far between with little to no emphasis on chords.  You don't have to worry if you mess up too much because unlike Guitar Hero or Rock Band you can't fail a song.  The game will simply take away notes to make it easier for you to play.  There is also the Riff Repeater tool which allows you to focus on certain sections of a song, slow it down, and change the difficulty if you are having trouble with a particular riff or section.  Within the last two days I've gotten close to entering Master mode on a couple of sections of certain songs.  As you progress and improve the notes will begin to fade away so that you will have to start memorizing the song.In my opinion this game is an excellent tool for anybody serious about trying to learn the guitar.  It is not a magic wand that will make you a master guitar player but it's a great place to start.  If you are not willing to put the time in and practice no tool or game will be able to help you improve.  I can honestly say that the time I've put into the game has at least allowed me to improve .  I still have a long way to go before I'm anywhere close to being good but I'm having fun learning and I believe that is what will keep me practicing and trying to get better.

												I have both versions of this game for xbox.. and now rocksmith 2014 on pc now that my xbox finally died on me. Though I feel the first Rocksmith had more of a reward system and felt closer to the rockband/guitar hero games. I Feel that this version is more inclusive and adaptive for the player. If a section gets to hard for you then it dials it back a bit, if its to slow for you it dials it up a notch. Now had they incorporated the rewards system (ie earning new guitars and venues from the first rocksmith) instead of the new amps and heads i think it would make it feel more rewarding.. With that being said I REALLY enjoy this game. I enjoy the guitarcade games and some of the changes they have implimented, there are some changes i didnt like, (the sessions menue wasnt much to my liking, but i can see why the added it and the way you change up your "gear" needs some improvement) but all in all  i feel this is a good game for people who are learning guitar or want to add some knowledge to what they already know and get started learning songs quick.

content:
2016
												Have you ever played one of those plastic toys? You know those toys that you jammed so hard on with a rubber band to master Through the Fire and The Flames..  and those baby plastic toys broke within months due to shredding 5 colored buttons for Guitar Hero? Well yea, you had a dream didn't you? A dream that you could intentionally smash that piece of crap plastic and pick up a solid piece of wood.. You know.. Wood with strings, tuning pegs, and.. real wood.                                       Guess what.. Ubisoft had the same dream.. But unlike you.. they made it a reality.. and here it is, Rocksmith 2014! Rocksmith had came out in late 2011 and was a game that you had a simple cable plugged into the guitar in one end.. and the other end of the cable going into your computer or console. The game was meant for anyone of any skill. But for people who do not know how to play guitar, this was an amazing teaching device. 3 years later Ubisoft released a new Rocksmith.. Also known as Rocksmith 2014. This jamming game was a kick A** version of their original game with improvements to almost everything from visuals to lag compensation. This is a dream come true. At first I thought it was a big gimmick.. but only a month later I already felt like a true rockstar. I went from not knowing how to tune a guitar to knowing how to play Chop Suey by System of a Down. And if you bought this game.. some of you may be wondering.. "Um.  How did you get Chop Suey? I don't see that in the game.. I also don't see it in the DLC store. I am very confused.."   Well let me help you out:  CDLC (or Custom Downloadable Content). This is content created by the community (Not to be confused with Steam's built in Community Workshop).. There are many videos out there on Youtube and plenty of guides people have created on both the internet and Steam that explain how to do this. Please remember this is NOT official Ubisoft material! Ubisoft has allowed this to be done but they do not endorse it. Remember this is not a work around to Ubisofts offical released DLC you buy through the Steam store. That is considered copyright and is not allowed! But anyways back onto the game, Rocksmith 2014 is an amazing game. It does not matter if you are Van Halen or some little boy from Germany who has made his way to the United States with very little money and nothing but a computer and a guitar but has no knowledge of how to shred! There is a skill level for everyone! You will never regret this purchase, as long as you want to play guitar and are willing to buy a Guitar and Rocksmith 2014. You are all set. (Please remember if you buy the digital version of Rocksmith / Rocksmith 2014 you must own the OFFICIAL licensed USB - 1/4 Cable Rocksmith sells. Third party adapters will not work. The cables work cross platform.. so the same cable you buy for Xbox360 will work on PS3 and PC and vice versa).  Do I need to say more? Buy it!Edit: October 4th, 2016; Ubisoft just did a big update "Remastering" the game. It is amazing they are still showing their support for this game! If you have not bought this yet, I highly reccomend it still!

content:
er 8, 2014
												Let's get down to business... This game was certainly one of Ubisoft's best games. You require an Electric guitar/bass guitar and a Rocksmith Real Tone cable in order to play this game. But I'm very impressed with how it worked, I understand that there are so many glitches in this game, but when the game works, it is just amazing.To simply state upsides and downsides, I'll list them:Pro's:You can learn guitar easily.There are many songs to choose from whether it's Rocksmith 2012/2014, DLC, or CDLC.You can get a Rocksmith 2012 import for Rocksmith 2014 giving Rocksmith 2014 a lot of Rocksmith 2012's songs.There are lessons and arcade games to play which uses the Electric guitar, it certainly helps.Missions to unlock songs/gear/inlays.Layout is simple and easy, whether it's the interface or the Riff repeater.Con's:For some, guitar is hard to play, I certainly had trouble, and that was beacuse I didn't practice the practice tracks, which I recommend you do if you're having trouble shifting/bending etc...DLC is way too expensive, asking £2.39 for a DLC with Rythym guitar, lead guitar, bass guitar and vocals... a little too much right? YOu can find all this stuff on the internet, but I buy these DLC's to help me learn the songs.Some CDLC may crash, and a while back Rocksmith 2014 just kept crashing when I started a song or lesson.Setting this up with a ♥♥♥♥. took me at least five hours to fix the bugs myself and get my guitar to be picked up on this game... thanks internet too.Missions... now, these... are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. I've never seen a game as bad as Rocksmith 2014's mission system... you had to do it... you had to be a bunch of idiots, put a basic coding into the missions, and from like... play 1 new song, you ask for 3. From a 10 note streak, you go up to 300 after a while, and you have to get 100% mastery in songs... and yet, no matter how many times I repeat the song, you can't get 100% mastery, and once it had bugged out and not registered. And every single mission is just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, allow for skippable missions and I'd recommend wasting time completing missions. I have to alt-f4 and launch the game to get a decent easy mission since I am only a beginner. Ubisoft idiots went too far with judging players skills, Beginner mode is what I started out as, and because of missions, they appear to think I'm pro. Also, there's no support for guitars with more strings. And no support for drums or vocals.About the stupid coding stuff... let's just say, there's only 2 songs on each path that the game recognizes, or at least 3. 2 CDLC's and one Rocksmith 2014 song... why not any of the others? Why not? Seriously, fix this or at least release an expansion pack that doesn't cost anything. But I recommend this game for the guitar player who wants to learn songs and learn guitar. But this is not for completionists, it is impossible to complete this game, it's just an unlimited game. For ♥♥♥♥s sake ubisoft, release updates for this, not DLC.

content:
4, 2014
												Fight Club is one of the most unique films I have ever seen. In addition to presenting a rather fresh take on life, FC also presents its material in a fresh way. My main interest in the film is in that, in my opinion, it does not present characters for us to think about. Rather, it presents actions for us to think about. I will say that I cannot recall *ever* having been "asked" by a film to both suspend my disbelief the way this film asks in its third act AND at the same time come to terms with an understanding that there is no room--or need--for disbelief.Perhaps these comments will not make sense to the average movie goer who will dismiss this film--and, unfortunately, its premise--as another hollywood flick filled with gratuitous violence. I'd go as far as to say that this film is not about violence. It is about choices. It is about activity. It is about lethargy. It is about waking up and realizing that at some point in the past we've gone to the toilet and thrown up our dreams without even realizing that society has stuck its fingers down our throat.I would argue that anyone caught, at some point in their lives, between a rock and a hard place--anyone who has reached bottom on a mental level--anyone who has uttered to themselves "Wait, this isn't right. I would not do/say/feel what it is that I just did/said/felt... I do not like this. I must change before I am forever stuck being the person that I am not." These people, they will know what I'm talking about. These people will not only recognize the similarities between Edward Norton's character and themselves--they will be uncomfortably familiar with him. These people will appreciate Fight Club for what it is: a wake up call that we are not alone.As David Berman once said: "I'm afraid I've got more in common with who I was than who I am becoming." If this sentence makes any sense to you, go see Fight Club. You won't regret it.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
er 8, 2014
												Let's get down to business... This game was certainly one of Ubisoft's best games. You require an Electric guitar/bass guitar and a Rocksmith Real Tone cable in order to play this game. But I'm very impressed with how it worked, I understand that there are so many glitches in this game, but when the game works, it is just amazing.To simply state upsides and downsides, I'll list them:Pro's:You can learn guitar easily.There are many songs to choose from whether it's Rocksmith 2012/2014, DLC, or CDLC.You can get a Rocksmith 2012 import for Rocksmith 2014 giving Rocksmith 2014 a lot of Rocksmith 2012's songs.There are lessons and arcade games to play which uses the Electric guitar, it certainly helps.Missions to unlock songs/gear/inlays.Layout is simple and easy, whether it's the interface or the Riff repeater.Con's:For some, guitar is hard to play, I certainly had trouble, and that was beacuse I didn't practice the practice tracks, which I recommend you do if you're having trouble shifting/bending etc...DLC is way too expensive, asking £2.39 for a DLC with Rythym guitar, lead guitar, bass guitar and vocals... a little too much right? YOu can find all this stuff on the internet, but I buy these DLC's to help me learn the songs.Some CDLC may crash, and a while back Rocksmith 2014 just kept crashing when I started a song or lesson.Setting this up with a ♥♥♥♥. took me at least five hours to fix the bugs myself and get my guitar to be picked up on this game... thanks internet too.Missions... now, these... are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. I've never seen a game as bad as Rocksmith 2014's mission system... you had to do it... you had to be a bunch of idiots, put a basic coding into the missions, and from like... play 1 new song, you ask for 3. From a 10 note streak, you go up to 300 after a while, and you have to get 100% mastery in songs... and yet, no matter how many times I repeat the song, you can't get 100% mastery, and once it had bugged out and not registered. And every single mission is just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, allow for skippable missions and I'd recommend wasting time completing missions. I have to alt-f4 and launch the game to get a decent easy mission since I am only a beginner. Ubisoft idiots went too far with judging players skills, Beginner mode is what I started out as, and because of missions, they appear to think I'm pro. Also, there's no support for guitars with more strings. And no support for drums or vocals.About the stupid coding stuff... let's just say, there's only 2 songs on each path that the game recognizes, or at least 3. 2 CDLC's and one Rocksmith 2014 song... why not any of the others? Why not? Seriously, fix this or at least release an expansion pack that doesn't cost anything. But I recommend this game for the guitar player who wants to learn songs and learn guitar. But this is not for completionists, it is impossible to complete this game, it's just an unlimited game. For ♥♥♥♥s sake ubisoft, release updates for this, not DLC.

content:
er 19, 2015
												A week ago, I didn't even know how to properly hold a guitar pick, and had no idea how to tune a guitar.  Since then, I've put about an hour or so a night into this.  Today, I went online, figured out I was able to read Tabs, and was able to play Saria's Song from scratch in about 30 minutes of practice.  I've still got a long way to go, but this is huge to me.If you're wondering if this game can teach you how to play the guitar, the answer is a resounding YES.  You will get as much out of it as you put into it.That said, the game isn't without its flaws.  It has a hard time reading certain notes, especially on my cheapo guitar, so you might have to play with the tuning to get it just right.  It also has a really hard time reading bends, making you feel like you almost have to snap the strings just to get it to read right.If you've always wanted to learn how to play guitar, but thought it looked too hard or were too afraid to try, get yourself a cheap guitar, the cable, and this game, and you'll get over your fear really quickly.

content:
er 30, 2015
												Remaster Update:They made some smart changes to the game menus, allowing you to more quickly filter and sort your songs. This is awesome if you have a lot of DLC. The overhauled Riff Repeater is great as well. I still recommend this game -- they consistently release DLC, and the quality of life improvements make the game even better than before.Original Review:I've been having a blast with this game. It takes the addictive elements of guitar hero and rock band, and teaches you real guitar techniques. There are lots of fun songs across all genres to learn, and the game does a good job of letting you ramp up until you are playing every note. It also has a cool "riff repeater" mode that lets you slow down and repeat sections of the song in order to practice. I've played about 50 hours of the game and I can actually play a few songs on my own already.There is also has a mini game mode that turns practicing scales, chords and other drills into games, which is more fun than just practicing those things over and over.My only complaint with this game is that it doesn't have very good tools for calibrating audio/visual input lag. I wish it had more robust tools like Rock Band does, because there's not much you can do to correct it. Overall, I'd recommend this to anyone who has had fun with Guitar Hero and wants to actually learn guitar.

content:
19, 2016
												First off, do ignore my playing hours. I've put this game down and restarted so many times my ACTUAL gameplay count would be like... 2 at best.Now, onto the review.The bad:Missions. Missions you say? What is this, GTA? Skyrim?!Yes, this thing has "missions". And that little rectangle will ♥♥♥♥ you off beyond belief. A good chunk of said missions are useless. "Play ____ in the guitarcade!". Yes, "guitarcade". You get to play little minigames, like a weird version of flappyybird or some kind of space invaders thing. Except with ducks. I don't know why ducks either.The idea is THERE, again, but the ♥♥♥♥ poor ability of the cable to distinguish various sounds makes it harder to actually hit anything. And god help you with the chord games.The tuners.There are two tuners in the game: one when you calibrate your gutiar between songs (eg. one that is regular E and one that is dropdown D) and the tuner in the options. The calibrating tuner is a piece of ♥♥♥♥. Sure, you can't expect your guitar to be precisely calibrated every time because tension physics is a thing. I would suggest using the tuner in the options more than the calibration tuner. It's more accurate.More songs than technique.The game has a lot of songs. Like fifty that come with the installation and an option to download more, assuming you're willing to shell out a few bucks. They're not too expensive, though I must say that I haven't tried to purchase any yet. Not sure how THAT bit would work.My guess here is that Ubisoft is going for the idea that if you learn a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of songs, you'll be able to rearrange the chords into your own style. Kinda having this whole thing as a secret, GIGANTIC tutorial.The good:The game does try to encourage you using recordings of a "hip" guy, presumably in his thirties who may or may not have played in a band in college and now his life is in shambles as he tries to recreate his glory days.He somehow sounds both happy and depressed at the same time. Not sure how, but he also has this "punch me in the face RIGHT NOW" voice.There is, in fact, an amount of basic explanation of how to perform various techniques needed for songs. Sure, there's no explanation of how to practice them, but at least you're getting information on what you can do with your guitar. Before I encountered Rocksmith, I thought you just hold strings and flail like a maniac.The basic pack is actually good!In many games with a ton of DLC, such as Rocksmith, the basic pack is there to provide you with a reasonable experience, ending up with you yearning for more. Usually, the DLC is stuff you wouldn't even ponder. Here, the situation is quite the opposite: You get quite a versatile list of free songs to choose from, and if you want to search for a song that you desparately want to learn and it's not in the free pack, it's probably in the DLC somewhere.There's a ♥♥♥♥ton of DLCContinuing my previous point, there is indeed at least one metric ♥♥♥♥ton of DLC. Assuming you don't get bored and/or die of natural causes as you attempt to bring all of the free songs to 100%... level...? rating...? You have quite a lot of DLC to choose from. So far, it's only extra songs to play, meaning, no equivalent's of Skyrim's golden horse armor plating. The DLC in Rocksmith is actually USEFUL!ConclusionIs this game fun? It depends on the personality. I personally tend to get obsessed with a game and the drop it for a year. As I'm writing this, I'm trying to get my obsession back up.I do believe that if you give it quite some time, you will master the guitar much faster than youtube classes.You may also end up in ER with insane calluses, bleeding fingers and possibly, bone fractures on your fingers and wrists, but at least you'll enjoy getting these injuries.

content:
er 24, 2013
												I can't recommend this game enough!  I've owned guitars for a long time, but never really stuck to practicing.  Most of the time before playing Rocksmith 2014, I would just fiddle around with making melodies and wanting to figure out how to make chords go along with the melodies I was creating.  I didn't get very far with Guitar.When Rocksmith (original) came out I was excited to pick it up and give it a shot, but had many issues with the game:  Input Lag, Audio feedback, and just wasn't really into the method.Then comes Rocksmith 2014!  So far I've put about 45 hours into 2014, and I'm still having a blast.  All of the issues I experienced on Win32/x360 versions of Rocksmith 1 have been resolved.  And now there is a recommendation system that suggests things for you to do.Rather than level up like in the first game, you focus on mastery of each song.  Once you have mastered a section of the song, the notes will fade out, and force you to memorize the patterns. (brilliant! and optional if you dislike it)I have yet to play Bass with this, but from what I can glean about being able to play Lead Guitar or Rythm Guitar, I expect it will be just as fun to play.  (I will probably pick up a bass soon; but there is a bass emulation mode as well for guitar)I have a deep musical background, and the only thing I find lacking is that it's all focused on Rock.  (But it is Rocksmith after all!)  I wish it had some classical guitar tunes that can be very technically hard, so I could focus more on picking and more difficult techniques.  But overall this is a great start, and I'm excited to see where this takes me after another 40 hours of play (or practice)

content:
r 26, 2014
												First off, I'd just like to say the big annoyance of this game. It is that every guitar and bass I own apparently has a really low volume. Every time the tuning screen comes up it says it. These are not low quality instruments. Apparently my massively loud Rickenbacker 4003 is too quiet! I don't not what guitars and basses they were testing with but seriously? So with that out the way I think I can talk about the rest of the game. It's fun! Though I'd question it's worth as a teaching tool. I picked this game up with 7 years bass experience, so I haven't really used it as a teaching tool. I got it because I'm a big fan of guitar hero and thought it'd be cool if I could learn some songs on the way. Unfortunatly, many years of playing Guitar Hero have made me quite good a sight reading this game. Every time I learn a song in the game to 100% or near mastery, I can't remember a single note when I come away. This isn't so much of a problem with the game as a problem if you've played a lot of Guitar Hero that I thought you might want to be aware of.This game has made me less prone to looking at the neck of my bass though. I didn't actually realise how much I did it until I started playing Rocksmith. It has taught me to only look down for the big jumps, which is cool. So it's not without it's uses if you're experienced.The big thing I wanted to get out of this game apart from another cool rhythm game, is a few new songs to learn that I otherwise may not have thought to. It has done a great job of that. I've learned Radiohead, Stone Temple Pilots, Dead Weather. It's all good stuff. Plus there are an enormous amount of custom songs available for download. They're easy to install and they're all actually of pretty good quality that I've tried. Not like they were in Guitar Hero 3. So check this out if you want to learn some songs. Though I haven't seen anything that explains any music theory to you, which you really need if you're starting out. So maybe only get it if you already have a pretty good idea what you're doing.

content:
r 10, 2016
												As someone who can legitimately play the guitar to a "mediocre" level, I probably wouldn't recommend this game as a tool to learn.Let's get this straight. If you don't play guitar, and you ask me if I can play guitar, my answer is "hells yeah". If you do play guitar and you ask me, my answer is "I own two but I don't play them as much as I like". Reality is I'm OK, but everyone else is probably better than me. I know all the chords, but I don't really know any full songs. I know a few riffs, and I know parts of some songs.This game basically lets you choose a song, and play it over and over again. To start with you have "not many" notes to play, it adds them in over time and adapts if you fail by taking notes away next time. It has a few features that let you slow down and increase the difficulty manually, but to be honest I didn't feel like this taught me much.Basically this game is a slightly more educational Guitar Hero. It lets you listen to some banging tunes while feeling like you're achieving something that will matter in real life. To some extent I guess it probably helps with dexterity and the basics of finding notes on the fretboard faster and hitting some chords/power chords.It does however have a really cool "jam" mode, where you can play like you're plugged into an amp and have AI play along with you. I probably used this more than the game itself.Don't get me wrong I would recommend the hell out of this game, but it really isn't much more than a "game". It's not going to teach you guitar better than online tutorial videos or a tutor. You'd be better of with those.

												Wow! It is everything it promises to be. I've tried learning guitar in the past, but got discouraged by the difficulty curve and the tedium of practicing. This software makes all of it enjoyable! From the beginning you're playing along with great songs. The notes are presented on a Guitar Hero-like note highway and the dynamically adjusting difficulty adds or removes notes depending on how well you're doing. Naturally, you can scale the difficulty and speed to your level, either in sections or for the whole song. Each song has its preset guitar sounds -- modeled after the original song -- but the software allows you to customize the sound of your guitar by setting up virtual amplifiers and pedals. You can have jam sessions with a vitual band. The lessons seem to cover pretty much everything you need to know and are well presented. The mini-games for practicing guitar techniques are all fun, excpet for Gone Whaling (which is about controlling the volume of your playing).I first got a cheap guitar just to see if I can remain motivated using this software and after a month -- averaging a bit over an hour a day playing -- upgraded to a much better guitar. I'm also buying a bunch of the DLC songs. Do remember that it takes a lot of time and effort to learn to play an instrument. Maybe this software speeds up the process somewhat, but it most definitely makes it fun!

r 5, 2016
												This game will teach you how to play guitar. Should you also look up lessons online and watch videos on YouTube? Absolutely, but honestly this game is one of the most amazing purchases in regards to learning I've ever made, and I already sort of knew how to play in the first place. The game will adapt to how accurate you play, but if its still too hard or fast there is a built in system that will let you change the speed or difficulty. There are also tons of fun minigames to help you practice getting used to watching notes fly at you quickly, so don't be afraid of that. There is a reason this is my favorite steam game, learning music and playing a video game at the same time is one of the most amazing things I could think of. The only thing that I don't like about this game is that they took out a couple features from the original that I enjoyed, which was the ability to select different guitars and have their tones digitalized. However, they more than made up for it with the crazy in-depth amp customization and super cool session mode that can quickly teach you an entire scale and how to jam with it. Overall I'd say this game deserves a 9.5/10, and I am seriously in need of a Rocksmith 2017 or whatever the next one will be called.

ber 17, 2016
												Alright, after 600 hours of play time I think that it's time I endorse this program.  I love this.  It is the epitomy of an ideal "game-ification" of an often times tedious chore of practicing an instrument.  With that said, this isn't a product for everyone.  If you are looking for the fun silly party game that was Rock Band or Guitar hero you will be seriously dissappointed.  On the other hand, if you sat down and mastered expert mode and played guitar hero for countless hours on your own so that you could say you beat Reverend Horton Heat's song with 5 stars then you will find Rocksmith to be an utter joy.  What Rocksmith is: The perfect practice tool.  Guitarists of all skill levels will find satisfaction in either the freestyle session mode where you can have a band back you up while you jam, learning to master lynard skynard's grueling runs or expanding your skill set in the guitarcade.  The DLC offers an genuinely insane amount of songs and there is enough there to sample virtually all styles of rock. What Rocksmith isn't: Something that anyone can pick up and enjoy in 10 minutes.  The guitar interface isn't entirely intuitive and just like learning to read music and tabs you have to learn how to read the guitar promts as well.  It works wonderfully, but honestly there is a pretty substantial learning curve.  It also isn't really something that you are going to enjoy with many other people.  If you shell out and get a second cord then you and a buddy can play, but still this is generally a solitary experience.  There is no online mode.So you think you're in? Buy the game and pick up the cord from amazon. Good luck and have fun.

content:
, 2015
												After a lifelong career as an air guitarist, and several instances of complete failure trying to teach myself guitar, I decided to try Rocksmith.  A couple of years later I'm actually a passable guitar player.What the game will not do:It won't make you Joe Satriani, Steve Vai, Guthrie Govan, or guitar hero x.It won't hold your hand or answer every minor question you have when you first start playing.It won't teach you all the theory behind the songs you're playing.What the game will do:It will teach you enough theory to get by (via some pretty generic lessons and mini games).It will introduce you to improvisation (session mode).It will probably introduce you to some pretty cool music you haven't heard before.Possibly trigger a mid-life crisis.Probably turn you into a guitar gear junky.But most importantly it will get you past those first HUGE humps to learning guitar - building callouses, finger dexterity, and getting in some effective practice.  The biggest roadblock for me on my previous attempts to learn was wondering WTF to play when I did sit down to practice.  This game helped me personally with that a lot since you can just flip on a great song and play along without turning the pages in some book or trying to decipher a tab.  The dynamic difficulty has some quirks no doubt, but in the end you can always manually adjust what level you want the song at (for those wondering how to do this, just put the whole song in riff repeater).  So even beginners can fire up Satch Boogie and just put it on the lowest difficulty and play along (admittedly even on lowest difficulty this one could be tough for beginners).    In the end, I would call this an extremely effective introduction for brand new guitar players, and a very good practice tool for beginners and intermediate players.  If you can't get into playing using this software, then playing guitar may not be for you.

, 2015

Cons are that to buy more songs you have to pay $2.99 for each and the Real Tone cable (which is used to connect your guitar to the computer) is sold separately so you have to order it if you buy the game from Steam. Otherwise fantastic game. Would recommend to all aspiring guitarists.

er 23, 2016
												Rocksmith is an amazing tool for learning guitar.  I started teaching myself (incorrectly) about ten years ago.  Before Rocksmith I could play a few dozen songs, but certainly not with what I would call skill or technique.  Nor did I have a proper understanding of the instrument, and thus could never just jam freely.This innovative program teaches players the RIGHT way, even those who have never touched a guitar.  Rocksmith includes lessons for beginners and seasoned players alike with many guitar-related topic covered from tuning and learning your first notes to power chords and solos.  Learning scales and technique is also made incredibly easy and fun through a number of mini games using the guitar as a controller.Then comes the best part: learning songs.  This is where Rocksmith is truly amazing.  In the beginning songs start very simplistic, allowing players to learn finger placement and tempo.  At first, difficult techniques and even chords are omitted so players can learn individual notes and strings.  If the player struggles, the song will remain undifficult.  As the player improves consistantly, the program increases the difficulty, slowly adding techniques such as chords, slides, bends, solos, and much more.  If the player struggles again, Rocksmith responds by intuitively lowering the difficulty.  Advanced players can indicate their skill level and bypass this process.  At any time, players can pause a song and practice difficult sections.  In addition, with each song, the program will make suggestions about lessons to revisit or sections to practice for improvement.  The base game's song bank includes plenty of excellent tunes to keep players busy with many hours of shredding.  When those are mastered, the DLC library grows constantly and includes a plethora of amazing music, both iconic and lesser known.  Please don't let the fact that Rocksmith was developed by Ubisoft turn you away.  The program is well polished, easy to use, and extremely responsive.  I cannot speak for others, but I have yet to encounter any type of bug or crash.  Please be aware you will need to purchase the Real Tone cable to play, and of course have an electric guitar or bass.If you are interested in learning guitar, or know anyone who is, Rocksmith is the perfect personal tutor.  And with it, you will learn a skill that will provide far more satisfaction than all the games on Steam.  Also the ladies love a guitarist.  Just saying.

er 2, 2013
												I was originally a bit skeptical but as the first game has been interesitng at the very least I decided to give this one a shot.I have to say, it puts the first game to shame. I had expected them to either focus on improving the "game" part or simply make the game more of a digital guitar tutor; which was the primary issue with the first game as it failed to really properly do either. Instead, Rocksmith 2014 does both, and brilliantly at that.As a guitar tutor it eases you in if you are new (as it asks your skill level at the beginning) and is, unlike a human tutor, infinitely patient. As I had previous experience (including the first Rocksmith) I was able to jump right in. The lessons are much more fleshed out; with several of the techniques having several lessons and practice tracks to play to really learn the skill. Most importantly, the Learn a Song section of the game is not only accessable, lets you choose what song you want to play and learn and do it. On top of this they made the Riff Repeater simply part of the Learn a Song, so if you want to go back and retry a part you missed you can do so. Slow it down, make it easier or max it out. You can do it at your pace and really learn what you want. You can even make it mark notes you missed so on th next pass you can be on the look out for them.On the other side of the coin is the game mechanics. The first rocksmith tried to instill game mechanics through a kind of "path" but really all it did was restrain gameplay. Instead you have free access to every song and guitarcade game from the first moment you start the game. Not only this but they have added a "Score Attack" mode which approximates one of its plastic guitar forebears, but with the real thing. The guitarcade games have gotten a massive facelift as well. Most of the games in the guitarcade are not only solid but assist in developing key skills; and most of them are references to old school games (I was particularly impressed with the "Rad Racer" reference game Scale Racer.)  One thing I don't feel goes in game or tutor sides of the fence is the Session mode. Essentially it can be thought of as a virtual band that will jam with you. They don't follow any particular song, and neither do you. You play what you want and they will join in as their AI decided to. You choose whatever instruments you want in your band, how fast, in what scale and go. The game teaches you how to play wiht the digital band (and even how to use this with a real band) and lets you have fun playing whatever you want.It is really interesting in that you spend some time with an AI band and you can adjust your sound to match the band; or just rebuild the band, or tweak it. Granted this doesn't allow you to write songs for the band to play; but instead it is what it says, a jam session. You play what you want and the band does too, they tend to be swayed based on what you are playing but you can even take more of a back role. Turn up the volume on one of the AI members and let them do their thing.Admittedly there are some faults with the game. Firstly and most importantly, a lot of the best and most popular songs are DLC. I understand that the base game is trying to pick and choose a wide selection, but when you put the B or C lister songs from an artist in the game then put out A list songs as DLC it does feel a bit wrong. Granted you can knock this up to the song licensing company having higher costs for popular songs, but it is irritating nontheless. Another thing is that occasonally the fact that the game doesn't catch a note due to the simply the game not catching a note will happen. Occasionally you will play somehting right and the game misses it. While I don't expect the technology to be 100% perfect, it does get irritating, and is especially common on palm muted notes. Overall for the price? This game is amazing. You get a guitar tutor that is infinitely patient, willing to repeat lesson after lesson and tell you when you do things wrong. You get a long list of songs to learn, even longer if you are willing to shell out a few bucks. You get a fully fledged rythym game where you can try to go for high scores. You get a slew of practice minigames that all focus on pumping up your techniques. You get an AI Band that will play along side you.And most importantly of all, you get motivation that may not have been there before. One thing any musician will tell you is that you have to want to get better to get better; and Rocksmith 2014 provides so many reasons to practice just a bit longer that you would have to try hard *not* to get better at guitar from playing it.
