er 11, 2016
												I've been playing guitar for about 9, maybe 10 years now and the biggest problem I've had is finding motivation to practise and learning tricky songs. Rocksmith manages to get rid of both problems for me. I've not had this much fun playing guitar since I started, it's 'note progression' system makes learning difficult or tricky songs incredibly easy and it progresses at your level, and even if you can't keep up you can simply pull it back a few stages to a level you can keep up with. It's helped me to learn songs I've loved for a very long time and failed to learn such as Electric Eye by Judas Priest (DLC song), Fear of the Dark by Iron Maiden (DLC song), Knights of Cydonia by Muse and Pour Some Sugar On Me by Def Leppard. It also gives you the option to learn the bass, lead or rhythm sections of each song allowing you to choose what you want to focus more on per song.To sum up, whether you're new to playing guitar, or you've been playing for years or even if you're looking for your first lesson, Rocksmith can definitely help you out, and I'd reccomend this to anyone with an interest in playing guitar.

er 23, 2016
												Rocksmith is an amazing tool for learning guitar.  I started teaching myself (incorrectly) about ten years ago.  Before Rocksmith I could play a few dozen songs, but certainly not with what I would call skill or technique.  Nor did I have a proper understanding of the instrument, and thus could never just jam freely.This innovative program teaches players the RIGHT way, even those who have never touched a guitar.  Rocksmith includes lessons for beginners and seasoned players alike with many guitar-related topic covered from tuning and learning your first notes to power chords and solos.  Learning scales and technique is also made incredibly easy and fun through a number of mini games using the guitar as a controller.Then comes the best part: learning songs.  This is where Rocksmith is truly amazing.  In the beginning songs start very simplistic, allowing players to learn finger placement and tempo.  At first, difficult techniques and even chords are omitted so players can learn individual notes and strings.  If the player struggles, the song will remain undifficult.  As the player improves consistantly, the program increases the difficulty, slowly adding techniques such as chords, slides, bends, solos, and much more.  If the player struggles again, Rocksmith responds by intuitively lowering the difficulty.  Advanced players can indicate their skill level and bypass this process.  At any time, players can pause a song and practice difficult sections.  In addition, with each song, the program will make suggestions about lessons to revisit or sections to practice for improvement.  The base game's song bank includes plenty of excellent tunes to keep players busy with many hours of shredding.  When those are mastered, the DLC library grows constantly and includes a plethora of amazing music, both iconic and lesser known.  Please don't let the fact that Rocksmith was developed by Ubisoft turn you away.  The program is well polished, easy to use, and extremely responsive.  I cannot speak for others, but I have yet to encounter any type of bug or crash.  Please be aware you will need to purchase the Real Tone cable to play, and of course have an electric guitar or bass.If you are interested in learning guitar, or know anyone who is, Rocksmith is the perfect personal tutor.  And with it, you will learn a skill that will provide far more satisfaction than all the games on Steam.  Also the ladies love a guitarist.  Just saying.

content:
er 19, 2016
												I've wanted to learn bass for what seems like forever; yet, like many others, I've made one excuse after another why I should not get one. Well, I finally got my bass (Fender Squier Precision Bass starter kit, btw) and was checking prices in my area for private lessons. Would you believe I was quoted as much as $300 per month?! That's outrageous! Then, my friend told me about Rocksmith(R), so I checked it out.     The first thing I looked at, of course, was the price. It was only $39.99 and I had to buy a special cable to plug my guitar into my PC (any guitar with a 1/4" jack input will work). The Real Tone cable from Ubisoft was only another thirty bucks. Here's the math: A total fee of $70.00 vs. $300 each and every month. Okay, so far, I'm thinking, "this is a no-brainer, but just how good is this software, really?"     Unlike your typical CD/DVD lessons that come with books and such, Rocksmith(R) is completely interactive, covering many necessary technical skills and even provides real feedback when notes are not played correctly, In addition, it includes several fun, arcade-style mini-games to reinforce the skills you just learned in the technical lessons, so you can start playing like a pro in no time!     Well, that's my review. I hope you found it helpful. I've told you how Rocksmith(R) is both incredibly affordable and amazingly innovative. Are you still wondering if it's the right time for you? Believe me, there is no better time than now. Come on, grab your axe! Your friends are waiting to jam with you!  \m/

er 18, 2016
												If I had a doller for every note this game couldn't detect... I'd have a lot of dollars...Seriously, though, if you want to learn guitar but don't know where to start, start with this game. It's got a lot of really good songs, technique lessons and various other cool things that make it fun even after playing 1000+ hours of it. The note detection may be a bit wonkey at times, but it functions like it should for the most part and even when it doesn't, it's normally missing really small detailed bits of a song. Also, the DLC list is really intimidating, but there are a lot of great songs in the base game including some new ones that are included with the Remastered edition. It may seem a bit pricey, and it is, but chances are, you'll get a hell of a lot out of this game if you get into guitar as much as I did.

												I obtained this game on Christmas, and I can truly say that it has helped me learn guitar a lot more than i could ever imagine. I already have around 25-30% mastery score on most songs. This game is extremely fun, and i very much recommend this game. I dont feel like i'm struggling and slowly learning, it just feels like im having fun playing guitar. Even though I am absolutely HORRENDOUS at guitar, I somehow still feel awesome while trying to play. XD although i sometimes get frustrated at trying to play songs, its still incredibly fun.The only problem i have with this game is... the DLC. oh man, the DLC song prices... For some song packs with 3-5 songs, they charge 7-10$ for it. And for specific single songs that you know and love and would like to play, They cost 3$ to buy. In my opinion, this is a bit pricy. Around $1 or maybe $1.50 would be sufficient. For some people, this may not be a problem, but for me it is.Pros:Good Song ListGood TutorialsNice, non-confusing Note TrackTeaches how to play guitar fast (at least for me)Incredibly easy to set up (need Real Tone Cable)Anything else that i cant think ofCons:DLC PricesCouldnt (yet) figure out how to get CDLC (customs)P.S yeah i know i have to get Cherub Rock, did that, and the customs appear in game, but they wont run8.5/10

												I highly recommend this game if you just want something the jam to every once and while, tighten your guitar skills, or possibly learn how to play in general. I used to play guitar in a couple different bands about a decade or so ago, even traveled the west coast playing shows and opening for some decent acts... then I went to film school, left the music behind me (fun while at lasted, lead to a lot of firsts in my life :) but never managed to sell all my old gear. I've hung onto a couple of amps, guitars with various sentimental values and rarity in the market place through several moves, but in all honestly only jamed on them a handful of times, and usually just playing the old stuff form muscle memory. Rocksmith is perfect for me with a variety of progressive difficulties, and challenges to learn new material and get outside my comfort zone. Been working too hard to play recently, but since I bought the game I've plugged in more in the last couple of months then I have in the last several years! The Mavericks bug did suck though, dragging down my ability to use the software for several weeks, took them the better part of a month the fix... guess that's what I get for jumping into a new os that hasn't been properly tested.

												I picked up this game rather cheap on the humble store, so even though I dont have many hours logged on this PC version, I have had the PS3 version since last year.This game has honestly made me a better guitar player and is a hell of a lot of fun. If you have any interest at all in picking up a guitar it teaches you right from the basics like how to hold the pick, how to put the strap on properly, etc.It is SO much more than just 'guitar hero except with an actual guitar' this is more than just a game, you can learn some serious skills using this and eventually surprise yourself. The only thing about this game is not only do you need to buy the game, but you also need the RealTone cable and a guitar(guitar isnt very hard to come by, goto a pawn shop, there is a LOT of great guitars there in need of a home).The only thing I wish this game had that the original Rocksmith had, is the ability to record yourself playing(some of us wanna be vain and see how badly, or amazing we sound when not in the moment of pulling off all this stuff). Other than that this game has everything I could ever ask for.All in all, this game is seriously addictive, and the dynamic difficulty was the song progresses means you can dictate how hard the song is to play, hell it was such a good game I bought it twice so you know it has to be good!10/10

												Initially this was alright, but the lag is really bad for playing. I can't stand it. Makes playing tricky fast sections really hard. Also its soo strict with actually playing chords. If you miss a note in a chord (or even play it a little too quiet) - it decides you havn't played it properly, even when it sounded perfectly fine (to my ears). Yet other times i would blatantly make a mistake which sounded terrible and it didn't catch it. It became hard to tell if i actually made a mistake, or the game was flagging false positives. I stopped playing after a while becuase of this.Several months later i was bored one day and decided to checkout session mode and worked through a few more missions. Then i fully comprehended what you can do in session mode. Its the perfect practice tool, i started doing my scales and playing along with the band. Now I just jump in session mode and jam for a while, practicing new and old techniques. As there's no critical timing in session mode, the lag isn't so much of an issue. I am enjoying it way more now.Overall i would recommend this game becuase of session mode. Once you had a bit of fun with score attack and learning a few songs, start using session mode and work through the missions.Note: I would consider myself an intermediate guitar player at the time i bought RS2014

It was only $39.99 and I had to buy a special cable to plug my guitar into my PC (any guitar with a 1/4" jack input will work). The Real Tone cable from Ubisoft was only another thirty bucks. Here's the math: A total fee of $70.00 vs. $300 each and every month. Okay, so far, I'm thinking, "this is a no-brainer, but just how good is this software, really?"     Unlike your typical CD/DVD lessons that come with books and such, Rocksmith(R) is completely interactive, covering many necessary technical skills and even provides real feedback when notes are not played correctly, In addition, it includes several fun, arcade-style mini-games to reinforce the skills you just learned in the technical lessons, so you can start playing like a pro in no time!     Well, that's my review. I hope you found it helpful. I've told you how Rocksmith(R) is both incredibly affordable and amazingly innovative. Are you still wondering if it's the right time for you? Believe me, there is no better time than now. Come on, grab your axe! Your friends are waiting to jam with you!  \m/

It's got a lot of really good songs, technique lessons and various other cool things that make it fun even after playing 1000+ hours of it. The note detection may be a bit wonkey at times, but it functions like it should for the most part and even when it doesn't, it's normally missing really small detailed bits of a song. Also, the DLC list is really intimidating, but there are a lot of great songs in the base game including some new ones that are included with the Remastered edition. It may seem a bit pricey, and it is, but chances are, you'll get a hell of a lot out of this game if you get into guitar as much as I did.

												Alright, after 600 hours of play time I think that it's time I endorse this program.  I love this.  It is the epitomy of an ideal "game-ification" of an often times tedious chore of practicing an instrument.  With that said, this isn't a product for everyone.  If you are looking for the fun silly party game that was Rock Band or Guitar hero you will be seriously dissappointed.  On the other hand, if you sat down and mastered expert mode and played guitar hero for countless hours on your own so that you could say you beat Reverend Horton Heat's song with 5 stars then you will find Rocksmith to be an utter joy.  What Rocksmith is: The perfect practice tool.  Guitarists of all skill levels will find satisfaction in either the freestyle session mode where you can have a band back you up while you jam, learning to master lynard skynard's grueling runs or expanding your skill set in the guitarcade.  The DLC offers an genuinely insane amount of songs and there is enough there to sample virtually all styles of rock. What Rocksmith isn't: Something that anyone can pick up and enjoy in 10 minutes.  The guitar interface isn't entirely intuitive and just like learning to read music and tabs you have to learn how to read the guitar promts as well.  It works wonderfully, but honestly there is a pretty substantial learning curve.  It also isn't really something that you are going to enjoy with many other people.  If you shell out and get a second cord then you and a buddy can play, but still this is generally a solitary experience.  There is no online mode.So you think you're in? Buy the game and pick up the cord from amazon. Good luck and have fun.

												I've been playing Rocksmith for 3 years now. I went into the game having given up on ever learning to play the guitar after failing miserably years before. When I saw Rocksmith for the first time I thought “Hey, I like Guitar Hero. And always thought it would be cool if you could play it with an actual guitar; might as well give it a try". I was hooked from the start. The lessons made it easy for me to get the basics, and the wide selection of great songs made it hard for me to stop even when my fingers were so tired and sore I could hardly play. 21, 2016
												Rocksmith 2014 is essentially an improved version of the earlier installment in the series, and I have to say that Ubisoft really nailed it with this one.The game provides a simple, good-looking and smooth experience for people to learn and play the guitar, regardless of skill level.With this game you can learn to play along to your favourite songs, practice your slides, harmonics, chords, play minigames in the Guitarcade, test yourself to reach higher and higher scores in the Score Attack mode and much much more.Being an intermediate guitar player that just picked up the electric, I have to admit that playing this game has been a blessing. Within the first five hours of playing I had already learnt more than I had after 3 years of lessons. The game is easy to use and gives you plenty of time learn the songs you love, allowing you to increase and decrease the difficulty and speed of specific segments with the Riff Repeater.The game starts off with a generous amount of songs for you to play, and allows you to purchase hundreds of other songs for a relatively cheap price with new DLC being brought out weekly. If there's a song that you want to play that isn't in the main game or any of the DLC, there's also a great chance that you can find and download a Custom DLC from any of the many community websites.The only bad things I can say is that the game might not recognize you playing some power chords if there's a lot of distortion going on, and that you have to go to a store and buy a Real Tone Cable before you can play.Buying this game is probably one of the best decisions I've made recently, and  if you are a beginner and want to improve your guitar playing skills, or if you're a master and just want to have som fun challenging yourself to clear Fury of the Storm with 100% accuracy. I suggest that you spend the around 50€ for the game and the cable, and go have some fun! ;)

												Around December of last year, I was looking for a good and solid method for learning guitar. I came across Rocksmith when I visited a friend. When trying it out on his PC, I got into the game immediately and it became very difficult to put my friend's guitar down. After that, I purchased the Rocksmith guitar bundle on Amazon and got it for Christmas. Rocksmith introduced me to guitar in an incredible way. The dynamic difficulty system started off with simple notes that gradually led to chords over time. As I got the hang of chords and techniques, I became better at more difficult phrases. Fairly soon, I found myself jamming constantly on the main menu. (Due to that, I purchased a Fender Mustang III to step it up a notch). The vast expanse of DLC kept me hooked with the game. I became exposed to more and more varieties of music, and I learned many different play styles. After getting over 300 hours up my sleeve, I have made it pretty damn far in playing guitar. Every cent I have spent on my new hobby has been worth it. You can say it has made a big difference for me in my spare time. I find myself lost in the music all the time and I don't mind it one bit. If you intend to get into guitar, buy this game. With dedication, you can achieve the skills to be good player. The only few cons that I can list with game are very minor ones.- I'm on my second Real Tone Cable (They don't last long, so handle them with great care)- Bugs on some occasions (My scenarioes are usually where the guitar audio will simply cut out and the audio feed will stop.) - Can't turn off Dynamic Difficulty once I reach a certain level. (I kinda wish that was an option once you get to that point)That's all I can really complain about. These problem won't hinder anyone since they are simple to resolve. All I can say to finish this review off is "BUY THIS GAME!"

												Plug in your guitar, learn to play songs. Rocksmith is pretty straightforward on the face of it. But underneath the hood are the tools that players of all levels can use to improve their performance, from Guitarcade mini-games, which make speed and technique drills better and more rewarding; to the Riff Repeater, which can slow down a single section of a song so that you can get it down right. A vast amount of DLC for this game means you should be able to build a huge library of songs you enjoy playing, and the Session Band lets you put together a band that will automatically play along with you.It should be noted that a Rocksmith RealTone cable is required to play this game, and that costs extra, so if you want to save some money then you should buy Rocksmith on sale. But any guitarist who feels like guitar games are a good idea but that implementing that with a toy instrument is disingenuous should look no farther than Rocksmith 2014.

												Overall I reccomend it, only two problems1: is the tabbing is not always the most efficient way to play, for example on Jimi Hendrix Little wing there's a double stop tabbed as fret 5 on the G string and fret 9 on the D string. That's ridiculous, in Eb those notes are B and Bb. You can just play fret 5 on the G string and the open B string. THe songs are full of annoying quirks like that. If you know the fretboard you can do the conversion but for learning, who the hell is revieweing these?2: The open note notation, they use a bar that takes 2 to 3 frets, when you're playing arpeggios in the lower frets (1 to 3) and lower strings (E, A, D)  combined with the other strings it gets REALLY crowded in the screen and it becomes really impossible to sight read.Everything else has been improving consistently and becoming better.

												I wish this game existed when I was first learning music. It completely lowers the barrier to entry for a starting musician. Years ago, you'd get your first instrument and make absolutely horrible noises for months, eventually graduating to semi-tonal, repetitive boring folk tunes. After about 5 years of hard work, you might actually be able to play something resembling a modern popular song. If you were practicing alone, you could only hope to simply play along to a recording if you wanted to hear the rest of the band. Enter Rocksmith - now from the first note you play you sound awesome. The rest of the band is there, sounding awesome. Next time you play, you learn a little more. You still sound awesome. Do a couple of 5 minute lessons, learn how to sound more awesome. er 2, 2014
												I highly recommend this game to anyone who wants to learn to play guitar or bass, or also to anyone who already plays but wants a fun way to practice. The best way to advance your skill as a guitarist is to play constantly. Practice, practice, practice - With this game, you can practice all the fun licks while playing a game on Steam. What's not to like?There are a couple issues that I run into though with my guitar - it's an older Ibanez RG100, and the hardware isn't as good as it once was. I think with the lower quality/older pickups and instrument cable jack, my guitar sometimes has issues playing clear enough for the game to pick up. Often times when I try to play around the 9th-14th fret on the D string, it will tell me I miss the note when I know I'm hitting it. That's really my only issue, and it only occurs if you have an older guitar. Simple fix is to upgrade the hardware if you have the cash, or better yet: Buy a new guitar!When all is said and done, like I said at the beginning: If you want to play guitar, or if you want a fun way to practice then you should definitely buy this game. Hit songs, weekly dlc, and fun mini games really sell the game for me. I have this game on PS3 and PC both with a ton of hours between the two. It's easily worth $60.

er 20, 2014
												In roughly one year I've gone from hardly knowing which end of the guitar to use to actually being able to play some tunes both on my electric guitar and my acoustic one. It probably goes without saying, but Rocksmith 2014 is the best interactive guitar tutorial out there, and I imagine it's a good heap of fun for those who play it more often than myself as well.I have so many superlatives for this game, and I haven't really found any big cons at all. The gameplay modes are both varied and intuitive, and the song library is highly relevant and ever expanding. The tunes they make available lend from all genres, from blues through mainstream rock to metal, and I've found several of my absolute rock favourites among both the included songs and the DLC.If you're looking to get more out of your electric guitar there really is no way around Rocksmith 2014. Be sure to look out for the original Rocksmith as well, it's a cheap way to expand your song library with a decent amount of tunes.

Feels more like a console game than a PC game in that way.EDIT: see comments for a link about RockSmith2014 Remastered edition. Sounds like they are giving us a 'core game' update. But with that said there isnt really any competition making this the best of its kind. My only complaints are things like not enough minigames, not enough options for sorting songs and making playlists, and just some general interfacing issues.  The core gameplay itself is still really solid.

y 23, 2015
												Awesome, awesome game.  I've been playing guitar on and off for about 7 years now.  Rocksmith is amazing for helping to focus my practice efforts.  At times when I want to just sit down for 30 minutes and play, Rocksmith is there waiting for me.I think it is dangerous to use Rocksmith as a sole teaching device, as some of the more subtle aspects of playing, such as proper position, picking technique, fingering technique, etc, will be overlooked in Rocksmith.With that caveat, this is an awesome, awesome game.  Guitar Hero - with real guitars!

21, 2016
												Rocksmith 2014 is essentially an improved version of the earlier installment in the series, and I have to say that Ubisoft really nailed it with this one.The game provides a simple, good-looking and smooth experience for people to learn and play the guitar, regardless of skill level.With this game you can learn to play along to your favourite songs, practice your slides, harmonics, chords, play minigames in the Guitarcade, test yourself to reach higher and higher scores in the Score Attack mode and much much more.Being an intermediate guitar player that just picked up the electric, I have to admit that playing this game has been a blessing. Within the first five hours of playing I had already learnt more than I had after 3 years of lessons. The game is easy to use and gives you plenty of time learn the songs you love, allowing you to increase and decrease the difficulty and speed of specific segments with the Riff Repeater.The game starts off with a generous amount of songs for you to play, and allows you to purchase hundreds of other songs for a relatively cheap price with new DLC being brought out weekly. If there's a song that you want to play that isn't in the main game or any of the DLC, there's also a great chance that you can find and download a Custom DLC from any of the many community websites.The only bad things I can say is that the game might not recognize you playing some power chords if there's a lot of distortion going on, and that you have to go to a store and buy a Real Tone Cable before you can play.Buying this game is probably one of the best decisions I've made recently, and  if you are a beginner and want to improve your guitar playing skills, or if you're a master and just want to have som fun challenging yourself to clear Fury of the Storm with 100% accuracy. I suggest that you spend the around 50€ for the game and the cable, and go have some fun! ;)

I hope they keep improving and putting out new tunes as well as make a new version in the future. Strongly recommended!

												Highly recommended for beginner, intermediate, or advanced guitaristThis is a great way to learn guitar. I know it doesn't really cover all the technique you'll be using while playing guitar, but it covers all the basic thing + a bit advanced technique you need to know in order to be a good guitarist. Why? You'll experience yourselves while using a lot of features here.I'm gonna mention all of its basic features and its advantages:- Lessons, this is a great feature for a very beginner in playing guitar. It covers mostly the basic of playing guitar, from holding your guitar, using its strap, to advanced techniques the professional guitarist use- Guitarcade, a lot of arcade games made by ubisoft provided by you in order to improve your muscle memory according to the techniques, like fretting, sliding, and etc. There's also score attack to prove your skills in mastering a song. It's such enjoying ways to improve your fingering greatly- Learn a song, it is definitely the core feature of the game. They'll let you play at first then they recommend the lessons you should take, and it's been mostly helpful. Also if you want to play the song directly, but you prefer to memorize the song, then there's a Riff Repeater to help it. It slows down the song and decrease the difficulty a bit. This is a great feature Although there's a bit bug like when you use the tuner, sometimes it falsely tunes your guitar. But it can be easily solved by using the feature againConclusion: A must have game for you all. But I recommend you buy it in a retailer, not on steam. As stated by steam itself. "The Rocksmith™ Real Tone Cable is not included". :P

9, 2015
												I bought a guitar when I was 16 and it sat in the corner of my room collecting dust for 7 years. I found myself bored of the initial stages of learning guitar which can be very slow and unrewarding. Then I found Rocksmith last September.When I found Rocksmith, everything changed. Suddenly, the initial, usually slow process of learning guitar became fun. That, to me, is the best thing about this game. It reduces the harsh learning curve of playing a musical instrument by using fun minigames or allowing you to play along with songs even though you aren't good enough to hit all of the notes yet.Today, only 9 months after picking up a guitar, I can play fairly well because of Rocksmith. I can play a good amount of songs from multiple genres including classic rock, country, modern rock, and metal. I still have trouble with fast guitar solos, but it's something I'll get down eventually.However, Rocksmith is not a game that is going to entirely teach you the correct way to play from the basics up to being a master. It works best as a supplemental learning device and you should still be reading and watching videos and even getting lessons outside of Rocksmith if you're serious about learning the instrument.For most people, Rocksmith will do what it says it's going to do: teach you to play guitar. And it does that well. I'd give it a 10/10 as a supplement to regular practice and lessons (even video lessons on youtube). I'd still give it a 7.5/10 if you are only interested in the game itself and aren't going to be playing guitar outside of the game. All in all a great way to pass some time and learn an instrument.

22, 2016
												Definitely an awesome tool to help you play, practice, and just enjoy the guitar. I started playing guitar about the same time (almost a year ago as of writing this) that I bought this game, and it's helped me extensively. The song selection is pretty good, there's lots of variety for no matter what you're into. I even discovered a few indie songs I've never heard that I actually enjoy very much. Some of the songs are more difficult, while others are a good match for even beginning players. The dynamic difficulty is a really great feature, as it really teaches you the song slowly so that you can get the hang of the structure of the song before the game unleashes all of it at you. Even if you're playing a really difficult song, you can still enjoy it and not get completely overwhelmed by it because of dynamic difficulty. Something that was useful for me when I bought the Megadeth song pack after only playing guitar for a month...Whether you prefer chords and rhythm guitar, the bass, killer solos and lead guitar, there's for everyone.The gear unlocks and progress meters on tracks really give you something to work towards. Picking up a guitar for the first time and learning the basic mechanics is a grueling process that many give up on, but the game has tutorials for everything, even things as simple as how to hold a pick, to help you through the learning curve.There's even a website with custom songs you can add into the game. I've added over a hundred custom songs I've downloaded. The vast majority of songs I've added (even lesser known ones) include rhythm, bass, and lead as do most of the ones I've seen as well.Ultimately, if you've ever wanted to learn to play the guitar or bass, I recommend this game extensively. Even if you already know how to play, whether exceptionally well, or pretty mediocre, there really is something for everyone here. As a guitarist, this is easily the best game I own, and the most value for my money.

6, 2015
												You're going to read tons of negative reviews saying "I've played guitar for x amount of years and (negative remark)" just because this is a different way to learn. Well I've played guitar for 10 years with 5 years lessons and I can tell you that this game can teach you everything an instructor can teach you as long as you're dedicated to it. The one thing it doesn't teach you is how to read tabs, but that is super easy and rocksmith kind of prepares you for that. Scales, chords, bends, harmonics, vibrato; all the techniques are in here and they have lessons on how to properly use them and give you feedback on if you are doing them right.  The riff repeater is extremely useful as well and much less annoying than the original rocksmith repeater that would restart you ever time you missed one note.Overall I think Ubisoft actually did something really cool for once, (the cable is a little BS since you can buy a generic one at a music store for like 10 bucks but still cant use it because I guess cable drm is a thing now), I really hope this game inspires novice guitar players to continue working towards their goals.

												Absolutely love this game and the possibility's it opens for future musicians as they learn from today's great hit to those classics from yesteryear. 100% must have if your child is interested in bass or guitar. It will keep them more interested than that book, and or the instructor can at times by just making it plain old fun to play with no pressure whenever you want. I was nothing more than a vocalist and songwriter with very little ability when I got this and now I am a musician as well able to get the music out of my head instead of relying on another musician entirely like in the past. I still have a long road ahead in learning to flow live with seasoned musicians but I am branching out to do so and without Rocksmith I would have never got this far in such a short time due to my busy life and mass hobbies/study's. Hoping to release a few songs I am creating later this year and that in itself feels simply amazing.I need them to make a Drumsmith & Keysmith or Midismith as well for my other beginning study's I have taken up in the past few years.100% my favorite game

YouTube™ Video: Rocksmith2014 - Deftones - Around the Fur 98% Hard -- Practice standing up acting stupid 

			Views: 388		

			Someone requested I do some videos not sitting, figured I'd move around some while also trying not to break my office. This was a 1 take I hadn't played it in a while.		

 -- That's me at 500 hours practice.This is easily the best way to learn bass guitar I have ever seen.  I tried to learn using sheet tabs and playing along with songs along with some 1 on 1 lessons over 10 years ago and got nowhere but frustrated, and gave up after a couple months without ever feeling like I got anywhere.I have played 7 days.. we were snowed into a huge ice storm and couldn't drive and were stuck at home the entire 7 days, so I played a LOT of hours.. I might have played 30 hours worth of this game this week.I did look into the custom songs. Buy the Smashing Pumpkins "Chereb Rock" then there are TONS of external custom DLC for this game.. I think I added maybe 150 tracks via custom DLC website. The DLC prices for the games inside the steam store are priced outlandishly, I have no idea why they're so expensive when people will literally manually track the songs and give them away for free at the same quality online.. I'd pay 50 cents for a track with tabs per bass/guitar, a buck is reasonable per song.. but 3 bucks?  This is a price that is so high I cannot recommend buying the DLC other than the one song that enables custom DLC listed above.. Google will quickly show you that you copy a DLL file into the directory containing the game files, and buy that 1 track, then you just copy any other DLC you can find into that folder.In a week, I'm playing several songs with a profenciency level where I can complete them on the "hard" setting with no difficulty with a 90% or higher accuracy every time, I miss a note or two in some sections, I could probably adequately play in a cover band and play these songs live if I had tabs like this in front of me on stage.. It's that good.  You could track a live band with it and people could play kareoke covers of songs they had no idea how to play with no difficulty whatsoever once they got used to the tab system.  It's the most fun I've ever had playing an instrument ever.  These aren't the easiest songs in the world either.. some of them are fairly fast punk beats.  I'm trying to hit 100% on the Foo Fighters Everlong right now, and I'm convinced I can do it.  I just can't hit the section with the switch between the open d string and the 5 on the a with all the fast notes(I think it's still the a string in drop d) at 100% accuracy yet.  I watched a video of the foo fighters on stage I'm not sure their actual bass player hits that section the same every time either.  My tone is correct most of the time and I KNOW when it isn't it's glaring to me when I screw it up now.  I've never played any song on any instrument this well before. I couldn't endorce this game highly enough for someone who is willing to sit down and peg away for an hour a day at it for a month or so.. You'll actually be able to learn songs, and that's a hell of a lot more fun way to learn than anything.Tip if you want to hear what you're playing.. go to audio settings.. turn the music to 30%. Leave the bass at 100%.  Turn the game audio for sound effects to 50%, voiceovers to 50%, and crank the volume. It's got the bass too low in the mix for someone to really hear if they're playing correctly.  When you do that, I'm playing with a low end logitech 5.1 with a 5" sub, but you can get a very decent representation of what you are really playing.. Turning yourself up a lot in the mix will help you HEAR what you're playing though, and once you can hear yourself and can't avoid tone issues.. I had a dramatic improvement to the point where I'm flatly amazed.TLDR: I couldn't endorce this strongly enough.Edit: At 500+ hours now, I could play on stage in a band no problem if you have the capacity to play you can learn with this.

21, 2016
												Rocksmith 2014 is essentially an improved version of the earlier installment in the series, and I have to say that Ubisoft really nailed it with this one.The game provides a simple, good-looking and smooth experience for people to learn and play the guitar, regardless of skill level.With this game you can learn to play along to your favourite songs, practice your slides, harmonics, chords, play minigames in the Guitarcade, test yourself to reach higher and higher scores in the Score Attack mode and much much more.Being an intermediate guitar player that just picked up the electric, I have to admit that playing this game has been a blessing. Within the first five hours of playing I had already learnt more than I had after 3 years of lessons. The game is easy to use and gives you plenty of time learn the songs you love, allowing you to increase and decrease the difficulty and speed of specific segments with the Riff Repeater.The game starts off with a generous amount of songs for you to play, and allows you to purchase hundreds of other songs for a relatively cheap price with new DLC being brought out weekly. If there's a song that you want to play that isn't in the main game or any of the DLC, there's also a great chance that you can find and download a Custom DLC from any of the many community websites.The only bad things I can say is that the game might not recognize you playing some power chords if there's a lot of distortion going on, and that you have to go to a store and buy a Real Tone Cable before you can play.Buying this game is probably one of the best decisions I've made recently, and  if you are a beginner and want to improve your guitar playing skills, or if you're a master and just want to have som fun challenging yourself to clear Fury of the Storm with 100% accuracy. I suggest that you spend the around 50€ for the game and the cable, and go have some fun! ;)

0, 2014
												Around December of last year, I was looking for a good and solid method for learning guitar. I came across Rocksmith when I visited a friend. When trying it out on his PC, I got into the game immediately and it became very difficult to put my friend's guitar down. After that, I purchased the Rocksmith guitar bundle on Amazon and got it for Christmas. Rocksmith introduced me to guitar in an incredible way. The dynamic difficulty system started off with simple notes that gradually led to chords over time. As I got the hang of chords and techniques, I became better at more difficult phrases. Fairly soon, I found myself jamming constantly on the main menu. (Due to that, I purchased a Fender Mustang III to step it up a notch). The vast expanse of DLC kept me hooked with the game. I became exposed to more and more varieties of music, and I learned many different play styles. After getting over 300 hours up my sleeve, I have made it pretty damn far in playing guitar. Every cent I have spent on my new hobby has been worth it. You can say it has made a big difference for me in my spare time. I find myself lost in the music all the time and I don't mind it one bit. If you intend to get into guitar, buy this game. With dedication, you can achieve the skills to be good player. The only few cons that I can list with game are very minor ones.- I'm on my second Real Tone Cable (They don't last long, so handle them with great care)- Bugs on some occasions (My scenarioes are usually where the guitar audio will simply cut out and the audio feed will stop.) - Can't turn off Dynamic Difficulty once I reach a certain level. (I kinda wish that was an option once you get to that point)That's all I can really complain about. These problem won't hinder anyone since they are simple to resolve. All I can say to finish this review off is "BUY THIS GAME!"

er 8, 2014
												I would like to start off saying that this is a very, very good game to learn how to play guitar if you are a newbie, or even if you are experienced it REALLY helps you out in learning songs if you're pretty shoddy at playing by ear or tabs. While it has its downsides, an exceptional downside especially for a newbie, is when you go to tune your guitar it very often may get your tunings wrong to a point where once you start playing a song you may be off by 1, 2, or even 3 (pardon me if I'm not very literal in terms of guitar) sections of the string, and it gets very frustrating when you keep missing notes thanks to this, and it's a real pain to tune it perfectly yourself while the song is playing, and I'll say this:  When I try to play System of a Down, those D Drop Cs are a B*TCH to tune and they are almost ALWAYS off, especially the two thickest strings. Which brings me to the fact that I will say GOOD LUCK tuning your 2 thickest strings because it is ALWAYS  pain in the a$$, especially when you try playing Ducks ReDux, you ALWAYS pray you never go back to your red or yellow string. But that is literally the only thing wrong with this game aside from there needing to be more songs (lol).Also a side note:  I think it would be much easier and much better to take regular guitar lessons from someone for at least maybe a month to get yourself much more familiar at guitar playing, and then warm your fingers up to moving with Guitar Hero, because that is what I've done over the past years. I took guitar lessons every Tuesday every week for at least all summer, and played Guitar Hero for maybe 4 years, and when I made the switch to real guitar on Rocksmith, well, lets just say I went from 0 to 65% on BYOB, 0 to 70% on Reptilia (not on this version of Rocksmith :( I have it on Xbox and PC), 80% on Knights of Cydonia, and I'm doing fairly well in Ariels and Toxicity, ALL IN ONE WEEK. Knights of Cydonia less than a DAY. So I don't know if maybe I'm just a natural or all those lessons and Guitar Hero really did helpI hope my review persuaded you to buy this epic way to learn guitar.

												I highly recommend this game if you just want something the jam to every once and while, tighten your guitar skills, or possibly learn how to play in general. I used to play guitar in a couple different bands about a decade or so ago, even traveled the west coast playing shows and opening for some decent acts... then I went to film school, left the music behind me (fun while at lasted, lead to a lot of firsts in my life :) but never managed to sell all my old gear. I've hung onto a couple of amps, guitars with various sentimental values and rarity in the market place through several moves, but in all honestly only jamed on them a handful of times, and usually just playing the old stuff form muscle memory. Rocksmith is perfect for me with a variety of progressive difficulties, and challenges to learn new material and get outside my comfort zone. Been working too hard to play recently, but since I bought the game I've plugged in more in the last couple of months then I have in the last several years! The Mavericks bug did suck though, dragging down my ability to use the software for several weeks, took them the better part of a month the fix... guess that's what I get for jumping into a new os that hasn't been properly tested.

22, 2016
												Definitely an awesome tool to help you play, practice, and just enjoy the guitar. I started playing guitar about the same time (almost a year ago as of writing this) that I bought this game, and it's helped me extensively. The song selection is pretty good, there's lots of variety for no matter what you're into. I even discovered a few indie songs I've never heard that I actually enjoy very much. Some of the songs are more difficult, while others are a good match for even beginning players. The dynamic difficulty is a really great feature, as it really teaches you the song slowly so that you can get the hang of the structure of the song before the game unleashes all of it at you. Even if you're playing a really difficult song, you can still enjoy it and not get completely overwhelmed by it because of dynamic difficulty. Something that was useful for me when I bought the Megadeth song pack after only playing guitar for a month...Whether you prefer chords and rhythm guitar, the bass, killer solos and lead guitar, there's for everyone.The gear unlocks and progress meters on tracks really give you something to work towards. Picking up a guitar for the first time and learning the basic mechanics is a grueling process that many give up on, but the game has tutorials for everything, even things as simple as how to hold a pick, to help you through the learning curve.There's even a website with custom songs you can add into the game. I've added over a hundred custom songs I've downloaded. The vast majority of songs I've added (even lesser known ones) include rhythm, bass, and lead as do most of the ones I've seen as well.Ultimately, if you've ever wanted to learn to play the guitar or bass, I recommend this game extensively. Even if you already know how to play, whether exceptionally well, or pretty mediocre, there really is something for everyone here. As a guitarist, this is easily the best game I own, and the most value for my money.

, 2015
												Rocksmith is the best ‘Jam’ title out of all of the others, you get to play the guitar. I can see on a really beginner level how this game would build up the confidence for you to play with some of your favourite tracks and introduce difficulty gradually in playing the guitar. Its great.This version doesn’t have the career mode which I really liked in the last one I played, here you just play the song. Im sure this was a decision made because it had to come out on those stupid consoles which seem to dictate at the minute if a game should be rushed out! We are all slowly turning to Pc boys cos of streaming and general utility, soz consoles, I think your days are numbered, but pc master race been saying that for ages! Anyway!The game has a great selection of songs, but as a metal goer I would say it’s a bit lacking in the real classics. There are community driven sites to get DLC and the DLC that is available from RS is pretty extensive so there are no complaints.The arcade is back which is a good thing if you really want to hone in on score attacks and generally gamery things. The game is top notch if you are a bassist and guitarist and certainly worth the purchase at any price .Now for the downside, this may only apply to experienced guitartistsThe only downside is the frustration of playing the song the way the game tells you to. If you are a guitarist and played these songs for years in your band and shred the hell out of the solos at lighting speed this is where rock smith gets annoying, its still fantastic but annoying!My greatest issue is failing when I can clearly play the song! Im having to spend way too long to level it up sections so that you are playing it near enough closer to the original. One of the gripes I have is when I play the score attack and set it to medium for a challenge presented within the game and find im not hitting it because its far too simple and unintuitive to me, eg, you just played trooper with your band and now have come home and started to compete online with the easy, med, hard leaderboards. You skip easy, because that would be just too easy, so you go to mid. You fail because the way its done the game misses notes youre playing it or doesn’t recognise notes. Personally I do better on the hard setting than I do on the others! Im not saying its useless its very VERY good but this seems to happen a lot and if you are like me and really want to go for high score you kind of train yourself to play it a way which the original artists didn’t! don’t get me wrong the tracking on this game is excellent and there are no issues really, its just the way you have to relearn sections over time as the game increases your mastery. It may be something with me and this isn’t a complaint anyone new to guitar playing would have, I just wish you could say, im a guitarist, set everything to 75% or a button which raises 5%. I spend that much time in the riff repeater learning how the game wants me to play is vs a way I play it. Great game though. Makes me keep the guitar out and constant practice one way or another!

21, 2016
												Rocksmith 2014 is essentially an improved version of the earlier installment in the series, and I have to say that Ubisoft really nailed it with this one.The game provides a simple, good-looking and smooth experience for people to learn and play the guitar, regardless of skill level.With this game you can learn to play along to your favourite songs, practice your slides, harmonics, chords, play minigames in the Guitarcade, test yourself to reach higher and higher scores in the Score Attack mode and much much more.Being an intermediate guitar player that just picked up the electric, I have to admit that playing this game has been a blessing. Within the first five hours of playing I had already learnt more than I had after 3 years of lessons. The game is easy to use and gives you plenty of time learn the songs you love, allowing you to increase and decrease the difficulty and speed of specific segments with the Riff Repeater.The game starts off with a generous amount of songs for you to play, and allows you to purchase hundreds of other songs for a relatively cheap price with new DLC being brought out weekly. If there's a song that you want to play that isn't in the main game or any of the DLC, there's also a great chance that you can find and download a Custom DLC from any of the many community websites.The only bad things I can say is that the game might not recognize you playing some power chords if there's a lot of distortion going on, and that you have to go to a store and buy a Real Tone Cable before you can play.Buying this game is probably one of the best decisions I've made recently, and  if you are a beginner and want to improve your guitar playing skills, or if you're a master and just want to have som fun challenging yourself to clear Fury of the Storm with 100% accuracy. I suggest that you spend the around 50€ for the game and the cable, and go have some fun! ;)

, 2015
												Plug in your guitar, learn to play songs. Rocksmith is pretty straightforward on the face of it. But underneath the hood are the tools that players of all levels can use to improve their performance, from Guitarcade mini-games, which make speed and technique drills better and more rewarding; to the Riff Repeater, which can slow down a single section of a song so that you can get it down right. A vast amount of DLC for this game means you should be able to build a huge library of songs you enjoy playing, and the Session Band lets you put together a band that will automatically play along with you.It should be noted that a Rocksmith RealTone cable is required to play this game, and that costs extra, so if you want to save some money then you should buy Rocksmith on sale. But any guitarist who feels like guitar games are a good idea but that implementing that with a toy instrument is disingenuous should look no farther than Rocksmith 2014.

												So far, this is an excellent, robust training tool -- RS2014 provides a guided experience, but gives you tons of options to go your own way if you prefer. I'm very impressed.I got Rock Band 3's Pro Guitar peripheral when that game came out, and the difference here is striking. Rock Band's Pro Mode was an impressive achievement, but the game was organized around casual group play. That was great for the "normal" Rock Band instruments, but extremely awkward for anyone playing Pro Guitar or Pro Bass -- learning new songs for those players was time consuming and would hold up the group, while everyone else could jump in or out and play things at a comfortable skill level, as the game intended.RS2014, by contrast, would not be entertaining for a room full of people. And that's good. It assumes there's one person playing, and it watches them, and tries like hell to figure out how to help them learn. It's as fast or (more importantly) as slow as you need it to be, and it understands that learning an instrument is a marathon, not a sprint.I haven't used Rocksmith long enough yet to know how good it is at conferring really advanced skills. But everything I've seen up to this point has been promising -- I'm having a ton of fun, and I know I'm learning. Definitely recommended.

, 2014
												As for Rocksmith, so far it's done everything I've asked of it, short of giving me a real solid feel of direction. I'm probably going to regret not practicing the basic scales and chords as much, since I've been playing along with some hit songs more during my practice sessions. The fun factor for me is quite high, but I've only found annoyance with the GuitarCade mini games so far. The lessons aren't nearly as in depth and useful as I had hoped. It's also hard to gauge my progression in skill outside of each individual song. I've also noticed it may be a bit too forgiving for timing. I've been singing pseudo-professionally, and feel the timing window might leave too much leeway for folks who aren't particularly good at rhythm to begin with, not giving enough feedback to develop well. 5/5

												Because of Rocksmith 2014, and probably only because of Rocksmith 2014, I've been playing guitar for 3 years. The 556 hours of game time shown above is only since I've been playing on Steam/Mac/PC in the last year.  The 1500+ hours I played on XBox 360 since 2013 aren't included.  You won't find many other games with this kind of replayability.  No form of practice has ever held my attention like RS2014.  Thanks to the skills I've "self-taught" through Rocksmith, I'm often near the top of the leaderboards.  Even if it were necessary to start taking lessons to advance to the next level, Rocksmith would still be the best way to practice.  Why play to sheet music of children's songs or 19th century classics; instead play to fantastic arrangements of 19th century classics, or better still, play along with your favorite bands.  Being able to play R.E.M.'s "The One I Love" while Michael Stipe does the singing or be The Cranberries lead or rhythm guitarist on "Zombie" is magical. It would be impossible to recommend this any higher for someone that has a desire to learn Guitar or Bass.  This not a button smashing rhythm game where being good has zero value.  Skills learned here are real and can be used to play in a real band on a real stage in real life.

8, 2014
												As someone who's been playing guitar for almost 20 years, I was excited to get my hands on Rocksmith. I've got plenty of good things to say and one very bad thing, so here goes: If you're a beginner who's never even held a guitar and just want to get a solid basis for building skills and having fun at playing, this is an awesome tool. If you're more seasoned like myself, this is a great way to get consistent practice and improve on techniquest that may have needed work or have gone sloppy over the years. I LOVE the Guitarcade. And the songs in this game are all pretty good (Muse--f*ck yeah!)The bad? If you're used to playing from tablature, the way that Rocksmith wants you to play is infuriating. Instead of common tab view, which is looking down at a fretboard, Rocksmith has you looking THROUGH the fretboard, which turns out to be counter-intuitive when you consider that almost all tab and instructional books/DVDs have it the traditional top-down method. Not only that, but RS refers to the thinnest string as "the sixth string", and goes up from there, calling the bass string the "first". Again, counter-intuitive if you've ever opened a pack of strings and read what they actually call them. Hint: The "first" is not the bass.Despite that glaring issue, this game is an awesome value and great tool. With the amount of actual instruction RS has to offer as well as good gameplay and great music, you really can't go wrong. Get us some cheaper DLCs and we'll be all set. :)

12, 2016
												I personally have a difficult time learning music others have written from sheets of paper.  I don't always understand the speed I need to play at, the way it is strummed, etc.  Having started appreciating guitar more from back when Rock Band was new, and countless hours with friends playing that and Guitar Hero 3, I was excited for Rocksmith.  But this is Rocksmith 2014, so I'll talk about it.This game improves on its initial release.  You have access to all the old songs, but now they are less simplified, closer to the actual song.  There is more variety for playing chords, again, closer to the actual songs (probably spot-on).  I can now play REAL music and still have little colored shapes going across the screen.  The game has improved my ability to spot-read, and because I'm using a real guitar and don't just have to get it "close-enough," it encourages me to actually practice the songs slowly so I KNOW what I'm actually playing.  I find myself actually playing bits of my favorite songs, even without the game, making it far more useful than my hours of Rock Band playing.  ^_^With the wide selection of DLC, I can still play many of those old songs for real now.  If I have any issues, they are relatively small.  First, playing Bass on here is terrible.  The system has the hardest time in the world registering that I have played notes in normal tuning.  It's far worse in Drop D, and  I have yet to find the "sweet spot" I need to have my finger in to get it to understand I'm playing F instead of .847E#/F...  I have a bass guitar and still feel like I have to practice it without Rocksmith because it's just no fun if you're hitting all the notes and it tells you contrary.  Equally, the game has trouble registering notes on regular guitar the lower I tune.  Drop D is tough sometimes, but it seems if I put my finger closer to the fret, it registers fine.  Eb has been alright.  But going into Drop C territory for Skillet and A Day to Remember has been the worst.  Most of the time I end up frustrated that I sound fine on the actual instrument, but it's not good enough for the game.  Last time I tried to play, I played very soft...the opposite of how heavy, deep, metal songs are supposed to be played, I thought, and it registered just fine.  Maybe I just need control.So for anyone wanting to learn how to play guitar for real and still have fun (yes, there are fun arcade games, though a very different lineup from the original Rocksmith...how I miss baseball...) this is the "game" for you.  At first, your fingers are going to have to get used to this because it IS work, and it is playing Real guitar, but after you build up callouses, you're on your way to sheetless rocking!  I have no regrets.

ry 7, 2016
												EDITED: Updated the review to account for the new 'Remastered' versionThis is a fantastic game to get if you are looking for something to suppliment your practice routine with. I would still recommend using lessons from elsewhere too since there are aspects of playing that Rocksmith does not address. However, if used as part of a practice routine it is just fantastic. Personally I use this most evenings, having a quick 30 min playing session to random songs for a warm up, and then spending another 30 or so mins working on a particular song that I would like to memorise. It's just a really great way to add some fun stuff to your practice routine, and given the variety of music on offer, chances are you'll be playing stuff you might not otherwise look at. Just this evening I went from playing My Chemical Romance, to some classic blues, onto a couple of disco songs including "Good Times" and then finished my session with a quick crack at Bat Country by Avenged Sevenfold. Pros:+ Gets you playing along with music from the start which is THE way to learn to play+ Has a very good range of tracks in the base pack, with loads of more on offer via the first game and DLC+ The tracks have a good range of difficulties - even a total beginner will find stuff that is manageable+ The Riff Repeater is great for practicing the tricky sections of songs+ Very little lag when used with a proper set-up (i.e. dedicated A/V rather than HDMI)+ Nice range of basic lessons to help beginning players get a feel for their instrument+ Now has very good search options making it easy to find tracks even if you have lots of DLC+ New interface in song-mode is much easier to use+ Riff Repeater now feels super-slick with mouse-based interface.Cons- Guitarcadce games are a gimmic best avoided- The note-recognition is a bit sloppy - you can play quite poorly and still get 100% on a song- Some of the menu design is a bit of a messAll in all, I really recommend this game to anyone interested in playing guitar or bass. Speaking from the bass side of things, we get the full deal too. Bass is offered for every track in the game, and there are some really interesting parts there. This is great since I had feared that bass would be somewhat of an afterthought. Kudos to the devs for making it a full featured part of the game.

												Fantastic game that has me hooked! Not so much a game more like a learning tool which is actually fun. I'd never have the patience to have actual lessons but this is something you can pick up whenever you feel like.  Some great songs on there and some not so great (personal taste) but you can always purchase more plus doing the missions gives you bonus songs and alternative tracks.

8, 2014
												As someone who's been playing guitar for almost 20 years, I was excited to get my hands on Rocksmith. I've got plenty of good things to say and one very bad thing, so here goes: If you're a beginner who's never even held a guitar and just want to get a solid basis for building skills and having fun at playing, this is an awesome tool. If you're more seasoned like myself, this is a great way to get consistent practice and improve on techniquest that may have needed work or have gone sloppy over the years. I LOVE the Guitarcade. And the songs in this game are all pretty good (Muse--f*ck yeah!)The bad? If you're used to playing from tablature, the way that Rocksmith wants you to play is infuriating. Instead of common tab view, which is looking down at a fretboard, Rocksmith has you looking THROUGH the fretboard, which turns out to be counter-intuitive when you consider that almost all tab and instructional books/DVDs have it the traditional top-down method. Not only that, but RS refers to the thinnest string as "the sixth string", and goes up from there, calling the bass string the "first". Again, counter-intuitive if you've ever opened a pack of strings and read what they actually call them. Hint: The "first" is not the bass.Despite that glaring issue, this game is an awesome value and great tool. With the amount of actual instruction RS has to offer as well as good gameplay and great music, you really can't go wrong. Get us some cheaper DLCs and we'll be all set. :)

ry 5
												Okay...review in progress. Also: first-time ever guitar player (using nothing but this and a cheap guitar called fazley). Learning guitar is obviously not easy and my guitar hero skills don't apply (alas :P ), so...Now I'm at 70 hours. This went straight up to my most played steam game, and no sign of stopping (I haven't even played all songs or lessons yet). Played for about 60 days, more or less every day. Have I improved? Obviously. Do I have fun? Pretty much the entire time. Have I learned to play the guitar? Of course not. Playing an instrument isn't a "you can or you can't" thing. It's about practice, practice and more practice. The thing is not to have it become a chore or hitting a wall. Without testing other means of learning to play it's hard to guess, but I think this does a great job of keeping things fresh and always having something for you to work on that's within your grasp. That, perhaps more than anything else, makes this something worth getting even for non-gamers.(older review)At this point (40 hours in), I can't but agree with all the other reviewers that it's a solid must buy (at least for absolute beginners). It may require some searching and tinkering, but there is always something to improve that isn't outside your (limited) expertise. Be it repeating that riff from Hey ya or paint it black, or just trying songs or guitarcade games or even practicing the tracks from the lessons.I'm not sure about other guitar learning software, but at least this does a great job of making your guitar skills measurable.Becoming good at guitar is still FAR outside my grasp, and that "60 days to learn guitar" seems awfully optimistic to me (I'm about halfway in days), but I'm still having at least as fun as the first hours (just kidding: it's actually far more fun).(even older review):I'm about 14 hours in, and still loving it. And that's rather amazing, as I just keep repeating the few lessons and guitarcade games I'm somewhat familiar with in order to not screw up. At this pace, it'll be 100'000 hours before I mastered all lessons, minigames and songs, but I'm having fun while doing it.Obviously, I'm not very far and anything involving bending or above is still way above me (I'm currently focussing on finding the right frets and strumming correctly). But at this time, I can say that the game certainly doesn't make you feel dumb when you're busy attempting things.Thus far no criticism. It's still way too early to tell if this guitar will end up collecting dust or that it'll sill be touching the thing two months from now. But I SERIOUSLY doubt that'll be because of Rocksmith 2014. :-)

3, 2014
												This game is excellent. I have been self-taught and playing guitar by tab for years. I could usually select any tab and make my way through it. This game finally introduced me to the theory side of music. **However, this game introduced me to theory by showing me new chords and new progressions/scales - I still had to take the time and learn a good chunk of the theory on the side. The difference... this game finally inspired me to do so!! I knew I had to understand these things to be a successful guitar player and Rocksmith ENCOURAGES you!!The layout/interface of the game and the options it gives you are phenomenal. Sometimes I find it annoying playing one note every 5 seconds in "Learn a Song" but Rocksmith quickly realizes you can handle it and adds more. Just wishing there was an option to get more notes/chords right away without having to use riff repeater to cheat the system.Overall, this game is great for any level of guitar player (simply learning a song - beginner/intermediate, to playing session mode for hours trying new lead licks or creating new music - advanced). Hope this review helps you out!

y 9, 2015
												This is an amazing way to learn the guitar, it's taken me from not knowing how to properly hold a guitar to being able to play the basic chords, play parts of leads and hold down sections involving multiple strings. Let me just list down stuff that other reviews might have missed, especially the ones that someone just starting out would want to know1. No need to get an expensive electric guitar, i've been using a signature guitar (Rs 3500) and a humbucker type pickup (Rs. 650) to play this. It's not the best way but it'll still get you started 2. Constant updates: Team Rocksmith (RS) is continually rolling out improvements and new songs for this. At about Rs. 180 per song it might seem steep but compare that against taking proper guitar classes. 3. Broad range of stuff: Formal guitar classes mostly focused on getting me to learn a particular song. If you follow the RS missions they'll take you from songs, to learning scales, to learning techniques like bends (each of which has its own game that you can play while training your fingers) to various tuning styles of the guitar. It's more holistic than just being able to repeat a bunch of songs 4. Takes the boredom out of practicing: the point at which most people leave the guitar is the long hours spent training your fingers to move on the frets. It tedious, repetitive and there seems to be no improvement taking place. Rocksmith makes that fun by giving crazy arcade games, easy versions of songs, score challenges etc. You'll play it for the fun and sense of accomplishment while learning all the key skills 5. It's not a perfect solution: You'll still need to visit websites/youtube etc to get more info on the basics. It won't teach you to read tablature (tabs) that real guitarists use to learn songs. People will tell you to learn the basic chords first (A, E, D, B, C) but Rocksmith seems to favor power chords. But it'll help you learn, it'll help you stick to the guitar when you would've grown bored and left it, and then one day you'll be a guitarist my son

Personally I use this most evenings, having a quick 30 min playing session to random songs for a warm up, and then spending another 30 or so mins working on a particular song that I would like to memorise. 17, 2015
Guitar Hero but with a real guitar!Rocksmith 2014 is an excellent piece of software that I really love. This easily goes on my favorite games list. It is the second installment of the Rocksmith series; the first game released in 2012. The new 2014 version has improved a lot from it's previous game.I picked this up with 0% skills and barely touched a guitar before. By the time of writing this I have 140 hours on records and without a doubt improved a lot. I remember when I downloaded "Take It Or Leave It" by The Strokes and tried to play I barely could keep up with the song and eventually miss a lot of notes, but now I can get above 90% accuracy in it. There are countless of DLC for R14 mostly for about €2,99. A must have is Cherub Rock by The Smashing Pumpkins because that allows you to download free custom DLC made by other people. Customsforge[customsforge.com] is the main website where you can get your favorite songs for free.Aside from the game you need a guitar obviously and Ubisoft's Rocksmith Real Tone Cable which works with all consoles, both R14 and it's predecessor. It is basically a 1/4 jack plug[i.imgur.com] to USB. The cable was pretty hard for me to get because I don't live in the USA so the store I bought it from had to wait for a new batch to arrive which took approximately one month.Happy shredding!

ry 21, 2016
												This game/learning tool is amazing. I had played guitar for years prior to purchasing this, but have always had difficulty learning full songs. This game with the riff repeater option has changed all that. prosI play on a mac and it works flawlessly with no lag during complex songs.You can change speed at which to play along withchoose your own path of lead or backup you can focus on one section of a song or lead or a few sections at your own pace in the riff repeateryou can change the difficulty and have less notes to start out with and ease your way in (caution though, as sometimes you will want to put the difficulty up higher than you can play in order to understand the best finger positioning for a certain chord or riff)intuitive on screen display allows you to play without reading music or tablatureyour gaming addiction will now actually give you a tangeable skill! DLC is forward compatible from the original version, so the song list is pretty robust. Just try to remember the game is called ROCKsmith, so there is lots of rock songs and metal songs, but not a lot of country or jazz.consthe steam version does not come with the rocksmith cable, which is required, proprietary, and costly. Any old midi cable will not do. Even if you have an electric or an electric acoustic guitar or bass...you will not be able to just buy this game from steam and be able to play. YOU MUST ALSO BUY THE CABLE!!! so I bought the game on sale for 10 bucks but still had to pay $30 for the cable, which took my broke ♥♥♥ months to actually buy. My advice is to wait for a sale on amazon or something and buy the game and cable together.other thoughtsThe mini games are hit and miss, with some being enjoyable and others not so much.some of these games have a hard time if your guitar's intonation is off, so yu may need to have it adjusted. My guitar has some intonation that is pretty bad, but for the most part in songs it still works perfectly....one or two of the minigames are unplayable...but that is my gear and not the games fault.there is a "session mode" which allows you to use preset jams to practice scales over, with a difficulty setting to even allow playing over changes and improvising. Buy the Ronda alla turca DLC from Mozart....it is so fun and if you ever get it down including the solo...you will feel great pride!I honestly wish this game was available 20 years ago. I strongly urge you to get this game for yourself...or anyone in your life who wants to learn or improve their guitar skills.

												Seeing as I have 200+ hours on this game and only 13 achievements you probably think I've been idling and probably haven't played all of the game. The second part of that sentence is true as I have spent the majority of those 200 hours playing songs that have been modded in by the extensive, constantly growing community.  When people think of modding normally they may think of reinstallling skyrim countless times due to corrupt files and installing loads of pointless software off dodgy websites. Rocksmith isn't like this. All you have to do is 1. own a DLC off the game (they cost a pound it isn't bad) 2. download a song of your choice off about 700 pages of songs 3. Change the DLCs ID so the game thinks it's the DLC you own. Thats briefly what you need to do theres tutorials all over the internet on what to do. I've installed 360 different songs onto this game and I've never had an issue.  When I bought this game I wasn't a noob to the games. I had played the original game which was alright and I had been playing guitar for years anyway. I've used this game to practice songs for performing and it has been very successful. The design of the game is simple to use and easy to play along to. This game is one of the few good ubisoft games (other great titles being king kong the video game and Howrse.)   In summary this game is perf if you want to learn or become better at guitar. Once you've played the base game theres a hell of a lot of CDLC for you to chose from.Only bad thing is you have to pay for "Smoke on the water" and thats just down right offensive.
